(i)   All color copies                              1.00 per page
(j)   CD-ROM                                        1.00 per disk
   (Ord. 2012-28.  Passed 11-13-12.)
 
   123.03  PROPOSED ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS.
   A copy of any proposed ordinance or resolution shall be furnished to each
member of Council and to the Mayor at least forty-eight hours before the
enactment or adoption of any ordinance or resolution, unless Council, by a
majority vote of its members, dispenses with such requirement as to notice. The
failure to receive a copy of any ordinance or resolution within such time
period before enactment or adoption shall not invalidate any ordinance or
resolution otherwise properly enacted or adopted.
(Ord. 1967-22. Passed 6-27-67.)
   123.04  MINUTES OF BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS.
   The Civil Service Commission, Planning Commission, Board of Zoning Appeals,
Architectural Board of Review, Recreation Board and such other boards and
commissions created by the City Charter and ordinances of Council, shall keep a
journal of their proceedings. The minutes shall set forth the names of all
members voting in the affirmative, all those voting in the negative, and all
those abstaining. The minutes of all meetings shall be forwarded to the Mayor,
each Councilman, the Finance Director and all department heads immediately upon
their transcription by the secretary or such person designated to record the
proceedings of the meeting. After due authorization and approval of the
minutes, as transcribed, the minutes shall become official records incorporated
into the journal of the Board's proceedings, which journal shall be open and
available to the public for inspection at all reasonable times.
(Ord. 1990-40. Passed 8-14-90.)

   131.01  PUBLIC BUSINESS NEWSLETTERS.
   (a)   The Mayor may prepare and distribute to residents of the City, subject
to review by the Rules Committee of Council, newsletters and/or factual reports
as to official actions taken by the officials of the City, legislation adopted
by Council, financial resources and expenditures and recreational or civic
activities or matters.  Failure of the Rules Committee to approve the copy of
such publications, within seventy-two hours after submission, shall be
construed as an approval.  Such reports and/or newsletters shall be used for
the purpose of disseminating relevant information to the residents of the City
concerning the activities and operation of the City government and shall not be
used to promote or detract from any candidate for office or political issue or
to influence the voting of any citizen.
   (b)   The cost of the preparation and distribution of such public
information newsletters and/or reports shall be paid from the General Fund
within items of appropriation approved by Council.
(Ord. 1993-21.  Passed 6-8-93.)
   131.02  PARTICIPATION IN STATE CONTRACTS.
   (a)   Council hereby requests authority in the name of the City of
Independence to participate in State contracts which the Department of
Administrative Services, Office of State Purchasing, has entered into for the
purchase of supplies, services, equipment and certain materials pursuant to
Ohio R.C. 125.04.
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City of
Independence to be bound by all contract terms and conditions as the Department
of Administrative Services, Office of State Purchasing, prescribes.  Such terms
and conditions may include a reasonable fee to cover the administrative costs
which the Department of Administrative Services incurs as a result of the City
of Independence's participation in a contract.  Further, the Mayor shall agree
to be bound by all such terms and conditions.
   (c)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City of
Independence to directly pay the vendor, under each such State contract in
which it participates, for items it receives pursuant to the contract, and the
Mayor shall agree to directly pay the vendor.
(Res. 1987-80.  Passed 12-18-87.)
   131.03  ODOT COOPERATIVE PURCHASING PROGRAM.
   (a)   Council hereby requests authority in the name of the City of
Independence to participate in the Ohio Department of Transportation contracts
for the purchase of machinery, materials, supplies or other articles which the
Department has entered into pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5513.01(B).
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City of
Independence to be bound by all terms and conditions as the Director of
Transportation prescribes.
   (c)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City of
Independence to directly pay the vendor, under each such contract of the Ohio
Department of Transportation in which the City of Independence participates,
for items it receives pursuant to the contract.
   (d)   The City of Independence agrees to hold the Director of Transportation
and the Ohio Department of Transportation harmless for any claim or dispute
arising out of participation in a contract pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5513.01(B).
(Ord. 1994-64.  Passed 9-13-94.)

   133.01  NOTICE OF BIDS RECEIVED.
   Whenever bids have been received for a purchase or contract involving an
expenditure of more than seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500), as
required by Article IV,
Section 2(c)(5) of the Charter, the Finance Director shall furnish to each
member of Council a copy of the specifications and a tabulation of bids
received at least one week before any bid is accepted by Council, unless
Council, by a majority vote of its members in the case of an emergency, votes
to dispense with such notice. 
(Ord. 2003-44.  Passed 10-14-03.)
   133.02  PETTY CASH FUND.
   (a)    There is hereby created and established a Petty Cash Fund out of the
General Fund of the City in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   (b)    Such Petty Cash Fund shall be in the custody of the Finance Director,
and the Finance Director is authorized to make expenditures from such fund, to
replenish such fund, and to account for transfers into and expenditures out of
such fund.
(Ord. 1966-33. Passed 1-11-66.)
   133.03  INVESTMENT OF SURPLUS FUNDS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the treasury of the City which will not be
required to be used by the City for a period of six months or more, such moneys
may, in lieu of being deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in obligations
of the City or in such other bonds or obligations as are or may be specified in
Ohio R.C. 731.56, now in effect or as the same may from time to time be
hereafter amended. Such investments shall be made in the manner and pursuant to
the terms and provisions set forth in Ohio R.C. 731.56 to 731.59, inclusive.
(Ord. 1982-48. Passed 9-14-82.)
   133.04  WRITTEN CONTRACTS.
   Whenever bids have been accepted for a purchase or contract or whenever
Council authorizes any other purchase or contract involving an expenditure of
more than seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500), the Mayor and Finance
Director shall enter into a written contract therefore on a form approved by
the Law Director.
(Ord. 2003-43.  Passed 10-14-03.)

   135.01  PROSECUTOR; APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES.
   The Mayor may appoint a Prosecutor for the City subject to the approval of
the majority of the members elected to Council. The Prosecutor shall perform
the duties of a prosecutor in the Mayor's Court and in the Garfield Heights
Municipal Court in cases arising in the City and shall serve as advisor to the
members of the Police Department. Such services shall be performed under the
supervision of the Law Director.

CROSS REFERENCES

   137.01  SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The Service Director shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to the
approval of a majority of the members elected to the Council and shall serve at
the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (b)   The Service Director shall be the head of the Service Department.  He
shall manage the Department which shall be responsible for the general repair
and maintenance of all public works, grounds, cemeteries, streets, alleys and
bridges, and other public places, belonging to or under the control of the
Municipality.  The Director shall supervise and manage the resurfacing and
repairing of all other municipal property, and the collection and disposal of
wastes and any other duties delegated to him by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1995-7.  Passed 5-9-95.)
   137.02  SALE OF UNNEEDED MUNICIPAL PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   Personal property not needed for Municipal purposes, the estimated value of
which is less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), may be sold by the Service
Director or a board or officer having supervision or management thereof, upon
approval by motion of Council. If the estimated value of such property exceeds
five hundred dollars ($500.00), it shall be sold only when authorized by an
ordinance of Council upon request of the Service Director or board, officer or
director having supervision or management of such personal property. When so
authorized, the Service Director or board, officer or director shall make a
written contract with the highest and best bidder after advertisement for bids
for at least two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within
the Municipality.
   When Council finds by resolution that the Municipality has vehicles,
equipment or machinery which is not needed or is unfit for public use and that
the Municipality has need of other vehicles, equipment or machinery of the same
type and that it will be in the best interest of the Municipality that such
sale of obsolete, unneeded or unfit vehicles, equipment or machinery be made
simultaneously with the purchase of the new vehicles, equipment or machinery of
the same type, Council may offer to sell or authorize the Service Director or
board, officer or director of the Municipality having supervision or management
of such property to offer to sell such vehicles, equipment or machinery.
Council or the authorized board, officer or director shall have the selling
price for the same credited against the purchase price of other vehicles,
equipment or machinery and shall consummate such sale and purchase by a single
contract with the lowest and best bidder to be determined by subtracting from
the selling price of the vehicles, equipment or machinery to be purchased by
the Municipality the purchase price offered for the Municipally owned vehicles,
equipment or machinery. When Council authorizes the advertisement for bids for
the sale of new vehicles, equipment or machinery to the Municipality, the
appropriate officer may include in the same advertisement a notice of
willingness to accept bids for the purchase of Municipally owned vehicles,
equipment or machinery which is obsolete, unfit or not needed for public use,
and to have the amount of such bids subtracted from the selling price as a
means of determining the lowest and best bidder. (Ord. 1972-89. Passed 11-14-
72.)
   137.03 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT .
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Administrative Assistant
to the Service Director in the Service Department who shall be appointed by the
Mayor and who shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. The Administrative
Assistant to the Service Director shall assist the Service Director in the
performance of those duties imposed upon the Director in Article IV,
Section 4, of the City Charter.
   (b)   The compensation of the Administrative Assistant to the Service
Director shall be fixed by the Mayor, within limits established by Council,
depending on the person's experience, ability to perform the functions of the
position, technical skills and work attitude, all as determined by the Mayor.
Further, the Mayor may, from time to time, grant increases within such limits
as the Assistant to the Service Director's skills and work attitude result in
an enhanced and improved performance. (Ord. 1986-21.  Passed 8-12-86.)
   137.04 FEES FOR THE RENTAL OF EQUIPMENT.
   The fees and procedures for the rental of Service Department equipment are
as follows:
   (a)   The rental fees for the use of tents and containers shall be as
follows:
 
TENT    RENTAL FEES

City’s Capital Improvement Fund.
 
CONTAINER                                  RENTAL FEES

   The maximum allotted time a container will be at a City resident’s property

   (b)   The Service Director shall establish rules for the rental of the
equipment (e.g. on a first-come availability basis and payment of fees prior to
use), subject to the Law Director’s approval as to form, by any City resident.
(Ord. 2014-47.  Passed 12-9-14.)
CHAPTER 138
Technical Services Department
138.01   Creation of Department; duties.
138.02   Department personnel.
 
   138.01  CREATION OF DEPARTMENT; DUTIES.
   There is hereby established a City Technical Services Department, which
shall be responsible and accountable for the planning, direction, operation,
technical repair and maintenance of the electrical, mechanical and electronic
systems of the City (i.e., buildings, utilities, communication devices and
systems, security systems, environmental systems, etc.)
(Ord. 1995-6.  Passed 2-14-95.)
   138.02  DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL.
   There is further established the position of Technical Services Director
within the Technical Services Department.  This position shall be compensated
at a level set forth in the City's compensation-exempt ordinance.
(Ord. 1995-6.  Passed 2-14-95.)
CHAPTER 139
Clerk of Council
139.01   Appointment; duties; removal.
139.02   Notice of special elections.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Charter provisions -see CHTR.
Art. IV , Sec. 2(c)

   139.01  APPOINTMENT; DUTIES; REMOVAL.
   Pursuant to
Section 2(c) of Article IV of the City Charter, it is hereby determined that
there shall be a Clerk of Council who shall not be the Finance Director. The
Clerk shall be elected by the members of Council at the commencement of their
term. The Clerk shall have custody of the ordinances, resolutions, files,
journals, minutes and all written reports of communication directed to Council.
The Clerk shall authenticate all records, documents and instruments of the
Municipality upon which authentication is necessary or proper.
   The Clerk shall attend all meetings of Council and prepare and keep minutes
of such meetings. In the absence of the Clerk at any such meeting, Council
shall elect a Clerk pro tem for such meeting.
   It shall be the duty of the Clerk to provide and publish all legislation,
ordinances and resolutions enacted by Council, as required by law, to
distribute copies of minutes as requested by Council and perform such other
duties as may be incidental and necessary to the office of Clerk of Council. 
The Council is authorized to appoint one full-time Administrative Assistant to
assist the Clerk in the performance of such duties and to attend meetings in
the Clerk’s absence, to be compensated as determined by Council within the
Grade Level 6 of the current Non-Exempt Compensation Ordinance for Office
Secretaries, Clerks and Assistants.
(Ord. 1995-28.  Passed 5-26-95.)
   139.02  NOTICE OF SPECIAL ELECTIONS.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council is hereby authorized and directed to make an
insertion in the Municipal News Highlites or a similar City publication,
notifying residents of the date and purpose of all special elections in which
City residents will be voting, as defined in Ohio R.C. 3501.01(D), including
special elections for other than municipal purposes, at least seven days prior
to the date of the special election.
   (b)   In the event of a conflict between the notice requirements of this
section and an individual notice requirement contained in the City Charter, in
general law, in these Codified Ordinances or in any other ordinance or
resolution, such other notice requirement shall govern. (Ord. 1982-7. Passed 7-
13-82.)

   141.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS.
   There is hereby established a Police Department for the Municipality.  At
maximum, its members may consist of a Police Chief, two Deputy Chief(s), four
Lieutenants, five Sergeants and twenty-nine patrolmen, if money is appropriated
for such maximum strength by Council.  Council may, from time to time, provide
for the appointment of additional police officers.  The appointment of police
officers shall be made in accordance with the City Charter.  The Mayor may also
from time to time, appoint deputy, temporary or part-time police officers with
the advice and consent of Council.
   The Deputy/Chief(s) may be removed by the Mayor for any reason not contrary
to law with the consent of five (5) members of Council.  Except for removal for
cause, if the Deputy Chief(s) was appointed from within the Independence Police
Department, upon his/her removal as Deputy Chief(s), he/she shall fall back to
the position held at the time of his/her appointment to Deputy Chief.  A Deputy
Chief removed from his/her position for cause shall have no right to fall back
to his/her prior position with the Independence Police Department.
(Ord. 2006-36.  Passed 9-12-06.)
   141.02  CHIEF; POWERS AND DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT.
   The Chief shall be in charge of the Police Department under the supervision
of the Mayor.  All members of the Department shall have the powers and duties
provided for such members by the laws of the State and the ordinances of the
Municipality and shall exercise the same in such manner as may be provided by
the rules and regulations prescribed by Council and the orders of the Mayor. 
(Ord. 1958-25.  Passed 5-27-58.)
   141.03  TWO-MAN PATROL CARS DURING THE NIGHT SHIFT. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Section
141.03 was repealed by Ordinance 1977-40, passed August 9, 1977.)
   141.04  DEPUTIES AND PART-TIME PATROLMEN; ADVANCEMENT TO FULL-TIME
PATROLMAN. (REPEALED)
(EDITOR’S NOTE:  Section
141.04 was repealed as part of the 1983 updating and revision of these Codified
Ordinances.)
   141.05  CHARGE FOR USE OF CITY JAIL.
   There is hereby established a per diem rate of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
to be charged by the Police Department for each and every twenty-four hour
period or fraction thereof that a prisoner from another political subdivision
is housed within the City Jail.
(Ord. 2002-71. Passed 12-10-02.)
   141.06  CHARGE FOR BREATHALYZER TEST.
   There is hereby established a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to be
charged by the Police Department for each and every breathalyzer test it
administers on behalf of another political jurisdiction.  (Ord. 1985-3.  Passed
1-30-85.)
   141.07  EMERGENCY SERVICES OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60 and 737.041, as amended, Council hereby
authorizes the Police Chief and the officer on duty in charge of the Police
Department to render the services of the Department to other municipalities,
townships, counties or the State in times of emergency whether or not the City
of Independence has entered into mutual aid contracts for police services with
any of those political subdivisions or the State.  The determination of “times
of emergency” shall be made only by the Chief or the officer on duty in charge
of the Police Department, upon a call for emergency police services by the
State or another political subdivision of this State.
   (b)    The personnel of the Police Department rendering emergency services
to other political subdivisions shall, as provided by State law, be entitled to
all of their usual wages and benefits, shall be covered by Workers'
Compensation and shall be immune from any liability arising from the
reasonable, good-faith rendering of emergency police services.
(Res. 1989-19. Passed 6-13-89.)
   141.08  JAILER.
   (a)    Full-Time Jailers.  There is hereby established the full-time
position of Jailer for the Police Department. The duties of said position shall
be the monitoring and supervision of persons detained in the Police Department
jail, assisting with meals and clean-up, and such other departmental support
services as directed by the Chief of Police. A total of four full-time Jailers
may be employed.
   (b)    Part-Time Jailers.  There is hereby established the part-time
position of Jailer for the Police Department. The duties of said position shall
be the monitoring and supervision of persons detained in the Police Department
jail, assisting with meals and clean-up, and such other departmental support
services as directed by the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police may hire and
train up to five persons in order to establish a qualified pool of Jailers from
which persons may be drawn on an as-needed basis, provided that no one person
work more than twenty hours within any one-week period. Compensation for the
position shall be determined from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 1994-86. Passed 12-22-94.)
   141.09  CHARGE FOR USE OF FIRING RANGE.
   In order to offset the costs of firing range upkeep and maintenance, any
outside law enforcement agency using the Independence Police Department firing
range shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day of use. 
(Ord. 2003-12.  Passed 3-11-03.)

Fire Department

   143.01  ESTABLISHMENT; PURPOSE.
   To better protect the lives and property of its inhabitants, the
Independence Fire Department is hereby established. Its object shall be the
prevention of fire and the preservation and protection of life and property
from and during fires that occur.
(Ord. 1967-11. Passed 3-14-67.)
   143.02  COMPOSITION.
   At a maximum, the members of the Fire Department may consist of a full-time
Chief, who shall either be or have been a certified paramedic, an Assistant
Fire Chief/Captain/Paramedic, who shall either be or have been a certified
paramedic, four Lieutenant-Firefighter/Paramedics, and twenty-three
Firefighter/Paramedics, if money is appropriated by Council for such maximum
strength. Council may from time to time provide by ordinance for additional
members. The appointment of officers shall be made in accordance with the City
Charter. The Mayor and Council may provide for such active auxiliary members to
assist the Department as may be deemed necessary for adequate fire protection
of the community.  (Ord. 2018-62.  Passed 5-8-18.)
   143.03  OPERATION OFFICERS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
143.03 was repealed by Ordinance 1990-57, passed January 8, 1991.)
   143.04  FIRE CHIEF APPOINTMENT.
   Repealed by Ordinance 1960-22, passed May 24, 1960.
   143.05  FIREMEN APPOINTMENT.
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
143.05  was repealed by Ordinance 2011-23, passed June 14, 2011.
   143.06  RANK.
   The Fire Chief shall be held solely accountable to the Mayor and Council.
All other Department officers shall be held accountable to the Fire Chief. 
(Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.)
   143.07  ASSISTANT CHIEF DESIGNATION. (REPEALED)
   Repealed by Ordinance 1960-22, passed May 24, 1960.
   143.08  DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   The Chief shall formulate a set of rules and regulations to govern the
Department and shall be responsible to the Mayor and Council for the personnel,
morale and general efficiency of the Department.  (Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.
)
   143.09  DRILLS.
   The Chief may call the entire Department together at his discretion for the
purpose of conducting suitable drills in the operation and handling of
equipment, first aid and rescue work, salvage, a study of buildings in the
Municipality and all other matters generally accepted as having a bearing upon
good firemanship.  (Ord. 1995-44.  Passed 12-12-95.)
   143.10  EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   The Department shall be equipped with such engines, apparatus and
equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency.
   (b)   All the engines, apparatus and equipment of the Department shall be
safely and conveniently housed and cared for and the same shall be kept clean
and in good condition at all times.
   (c)   No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private
purpose, nor shall any person wilfully and without proper authority remove,
take away, keep or conceal any tool, appliance or other article used in any way
by the Fire Department.
(Ord. 1010.  Passed 11-23-37.)
   143.11  MUNICIPAL FIRE SAFETY INSPECTOR.
   The Municipal Fire Safety Inspector is required to cause inspections  to be
made of all buildings and premises within the Municipality, with the exception
of those used exclusively for residential purposes, and to serve written notice
upon the owner of occupant to abate, within the specified time, any and all
fire hazards that may be found therein.
(Ord. 1995-44.  Passed 12-12-95.)
   143.12  ORDER OF ABATEMENT; COMPLIANCE.
   Any person so served with an order to abate any fire hazard or hazards shall
comply with the order and promptly notify the Chief of such compliance.
(Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.)
   143.13  POLICE POWERS.
   All regularly appointed members of the Fire Department are hereby given the
necessary special police powers for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.)
   143.14  POLICE CHIEF'S DUTIES AT FIRE.
   It is hereby made the special duty of the Chief of Police or police officer
in charge, and such other peace officers as are on duty at the time, to respond
to all fire alarms and assist the Fire Department in the protection of life and
property and in controlling and regulating traffic and maintaining order.
(Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.)
   143.15  COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Fire Department, including the Fire Chief, shall receive such
compensation as Council may from time to time determine.
(Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.)
   143.16  PARAMEDIC CERTIFICATION.
   (a)    All candidates for a firefighter/paramedics position shall
successfully complete a paramedic course and obtain a paramedic certification
from the State prior to submitting an application to take a firefighter
examination.  Thereafter, they shall, at all times, maintain a current
paramedic certification under the laws of the State that govern such
certifications, including any continuing education.  Failure to maintain
current paramedic certification throughout the individual’s period of
employment shall be considered an act of nonfeasance in office and grounds for
disciplinary action under Ohio R.C. 124.34.
   (b)   Subsection (a) hereof shall apply to all firefighter/paramedics and
fire lieutenant/paramedics who are appointed after the effective date of this
section.
(Ord. 2013-12.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   143.17  EMERGENCY SERVICES OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a)    Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60 and 737.041, as amended, Council hereby
authorizes the Fire Chief and the officer on duty in charge of the Fire
Department to render the services of the Department to other municipalities,
townships, counties or the State in time of emergency, whether or not the City
of Independence has entered into mutual aid contracts for fire services with
any of those political subdivisions or the State. The determination of "times
of emergency" shall be made only by the Chief or the officer on duty in charge
of the Fire Department, upon a call for emergency fire protection services by
the State or another political subdivision of this State.
   (b)    The personnel of the Fire Department rendering emergency services to
other political subdivisions shall, as provided by State law, be entitled to
all of their usual wages and benefits, shall be covered by Workers'
Compensation and shall be immune from any liability arising from the
reasonable, good-faith rendering of emergency fire protection services.
(Res. 1989-19. Passed 6-13-89.)
   143.18  PROVISION OF EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES; FEES AND CHARGES.
   (a)   A fee shall be charged by the City for each person receiving emergency
medical service from the City as follows:
      (1)   Basic Life Support (BLS) emergency transport one way - $650 plus
$15.00 per mile.
      (2)   Advanced Life Support (ALS) emergency transport one way - $850 plus
$15.00 per mile.
      (3)   Advanced Life Support II (ALS) emergency transport one way -
$1000.00 plus $15.00 per mile.  (Ord.  2018-190.  Passed 12-11-18.)
   (b)   The Mayor may enter into an agreement on behalf of the City to engage
the services of a billing and collection company which shall submit claims on
behalf of the City to provide insurers and/or the Federal Health Care Program
of Medicare and Medicaid and shall issue bills to persons using emergency
medical services for such amounts not covered by insurance only to the extent
provided herein.  Each person who uses emergency medical services provided by
the City shall assign any insurance proceeds available to such person to the
City.
   (c)   The Finance Director is authorized and instructed to collect fees for
emergency medical services provided by the City and, as provided herein, to
establish rules and regulations for such collection from any person, person’s
insurance company, or Medicare and shall issue bills and collect fees to the
extent provided herein.  The Fire Chief has authority to waive the fee, or any
portion thereof, if he determines the person is indigent or otherwise unable to
pay for said services.
   (d)   The Finance Director shall not bill or attempt to collect from any
resident of the City of Independence any amount in excess of the amount paid by
said individual’s medical insurance provider, or Medicare, including but not
limited to any co-payment or deductible.
   (e)   The Finance Director shall not bill or attempt to collect from any
individual employed within the City any amount in excess of the amount paid by
said individual’s medical insurance provider, or Medicare, including but not
limited to any co-payment or deductible.
   (f)   When emergency medical services are provided by the City personnel to
persons outside the City limits pursuant to a mutual aid agreement or
understanding with another municipality as provided in Section
143.17 , the City shall bill such person in accordance with the practices of
the requesting municipality.  When emergency medical services are provided
within the City by personnel of another municipality pursuant to a mutual aid
agreement or understanding, such person shall be billed in accordance with the
provisions of this section.
   (g)   Hereby created is the "Capital Projects Fund."  All fees collected
under this section shall be deposited by the City into the general fund with
the first initial $250,000 annually being transferred to the Capital Projects
Fund, to be used by the Independence Police and Fire Departments for the
repair, replacement and purchase of equipment or other fixed assets.  (Ord.
2012-19.  Passed 6-12-12.)
   143.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Sections
143.10(c) or
143.12 hereof or any order of a police officer issued thereunder shall be fined
not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 1010. Passed 11-23-37.)

Building Department
EDITOR'S NOTE: At the time of the preparation of the 1990 Replacement Pages for
these Codified Ordinances, the title of the Inspector of Buildings had been
changed to the Building Commissioner. References throughout these Codified
Ordinances to the Inspector of Buildings, therefore, shall be deemed to mean
the Building Commissioner.

   144.01  ESTABLISHMENT; PURPOSES; COMPOSITION.
   A Department of Buildings is hereby established within the Municipality. Its
object and purpose shall be the supervision and inspection of buildings and the
administration and enforcement of Part Thirteen of the Codified Ordinances,
such part being known as the Building Code, and the administration and
enforcement of all other laws and ordinances relating to the creation,
construction, alteration, repair, removal and safety of buildings, structures
and improvements and appurtenances thereto. The Department shall be composed of
one full-time Building Commissioner and such assistant commissioners, part-time
commissioners and other full or part-time employees as are authorized for
payment by Council. (Ord. 1977-8. Passed 2-8-77.)
   144.02  DUTIES OF COMMISSIONER; OTHER EMPLOYEES .
   The Building Commissioner shall be the head of the Building Department and
shall administer Part Thirteen of these Codified Ordinances and have all of the
duties set forth therein and in Section
144.01. Other full or part-time commissioners or employees of the Building
Department shall be appointed by the Mayor, and Council shall fix their
salaries or compensation. (Ord. 1977-8. Passed 2-8-77. )
   144.03  ASSISTANT BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   (a)    There is hereby created the part-time position of Assistant Building
Commissioner, who shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
Said Assistant Building Commissioner shall report to the Building Commissioner
and shall enforce the provisions of Part Thirteen of these Codified Ordinances
-  the Building Code, with additional specific responsibility for zoning
enforcement pursuant to Chapter
1125 of these Codified Ordinances, as well as residential development and new
housing starts.
   (b)    The person appointed to the part-time position of Assistant Building
Commissioner shall be compensated at a rate determined by the Mayor based on
said employee's experience, performance and attitude.
(Ord. 1988-23. Passed 8-9-88.)

CHAPTER 150
Insurance Requirements for Providers of Professional Services
150.01   Definitions.
150.02   Insurance required.
   150.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Professional liability insurance” means insurance which covers a
person or organization for loss or damage to third parties arising from
negligent acts, errors and/or omissions in rendering professional services.
(Ord. 2003-08.  Passed 1-14-03.)
   (b)   “Professional services” means work, assistance, information or advice
performed or provided to the City which is based on a recognized standard of
specialized knowledge or expertise, including but not limited to law,
accounting, appraising, architecture, and engineering, often requiring
extensive formal education and licensure or certification.
(Ord. 2004-34.  Passed 8-10-04.)
   (c)   “Errors and omissions insurance” means professional liability
insurance.
(Ord. 2003-08.  Passed 1-14-03.)
   150.02  INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   Individuals, firms, corporations or businesses providing professional
services to the City under a contract or agreement entered into after the
effective date hereof are required to secure and maintain professional
liability insurance and/or errors and omissions insurance in the amount of one
million dollars ($1,000,000), or such other amount as may be determined by the
Mayor to be necessary and appropriate, to cover losses resulting from
professional negligence in the performance or professional services for the
City.
(Ord. 2003-08.  Passed 1-14-03.)

   151.01  ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPARTMENT.

Municipality. Its object shall be to care for and maintain Elmwood Park and
Municipal Recreation Center and other Municipal recreation areas and to
implement and provide a complete recreation program for all residents of the
City. The Department shall be composed of one full-time Recreation Director and
such other full or part-time employees as are authorized by Council.
(Ord. 1986-13. Passed 7-4-86; Res. 1989-41. Passed 8-8-89.)
   151.02  RECREATION DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; DUTIES.
   The Recreation Director shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to the
approval of a majority of the members of Council, with tenure of office during
good behavior and efficient service. The Mayor may remove the Director for
cause and with the consent of five members of Council. However, the Director
shall be given the right to be heard at an official meeting of Council before
its consent to his or her removal is given. The Recreation Board shall
interview and submit a list of candidates to the Mayor, with its
recommendations, out of which he or she may make the appointment. The Director
shall have at least four years of college training in the recreation field or
two years of college training and two years of actual work experience in the
public recreation field. The Director shall be the head of the Parks and
Recreation Department and shall have authority over and manage such Department,
as well as carry out the overall recreation program of the Municipality,
subject to the supervision of the Mayor. Employees of the Department and
employees from another department assigned by the Mayor to work in Elmwood Park
and Municipal Recreation Center shall be under the direct supervision and
control of the Director in the performance of their respective duties.
(Ord. 1986-13. Passed 7-4-86; Res. 1989-41. Passed 8-8-89.)
   151.03  ESTABLISHMENT OF POSITIONS; COMPENSATION; RECREATION FUNDS.
   Council shall provide by ordinance for any other positions to be established
in the Parks and Recreation Department and shall provide for the rates of
compensation to be paid for such positions. The Finance Director shall maintain
appropriate recreation funds into which all receipts and revenue of the
recreation program shall be deposited and entered and from which payment shall
be made for the salaries, wages and other expenses for the operation of the
recreation program.
(Ord. 1976-25. Passed 5-11-76.)
   151.04  ESTABLISHMENT OF BOARD.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 151.04 was repealed by Ordinance 1996-10,
passed September 10, 1996.)
   151.05  MEMBERS OF BOARD.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 151.05 was repealed by Ordinance 1996-10,
passed September 10, 1996.)
   151.06  OFFICERS; ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 151.06 was repealed by Ordinance 1996-10,
passed September 10, 1996.)
   151.07  BUDGET AND FINANCES.
   On or before the first day of every year, the annual budget for the Parks
and Recreation Department shall be presented to the Mayor by the Recreation
Director for approval and for appropriation of funds. The Director shall not
obligate the Municipality to spend any funds, except such as may be
appropriated or authorized to be spent by Council. The Director shall be
responsible for the financial aspects of the Department and the recreation
program.  The Director shall dispense moneys for the Department within the
amounts appropriated by Council, and shall prepare a monthly summary of the
receipts and expenditures within the Department, which he shall present to the
Mayor and the Finance Director.  (Ord. 1996-10.  Passed 9-10-96.)
   151.08  LONG RANGE RECREATION PLANNING.
   The Recreation Director shall be responsible for the implementation of
recreation programs and rules and regulations regarding such programs, the
daily management of the Parks and Recreation Department and any disciplinary
matters concerning either.  However, in the implementation of long-range
planning for recreation programs and major capital improvements for inclusion
in the annual budget and in such matters as the participation fees and the use
of recreational facilities, the Director and the Community Services Committee
of Council shall act jointly.  On such matters the determination shall be made
by the Director and a majority of the members of Council, provided, however,
that if no agreement is reached, the unanimous decision of the Mayor and the
Council shall be decisive.
(Ord. 1996-10.  Passed 9-10-96.)
   151.09  TRESPASSING AT ELMWOOD PARK AND MUNICIPAL RECREATION CENTER.
   No person shall loiter, congregate, gather or use any facility of the
Elmwood Park and Municipal Recreation Center or be in or upon its grounds or
roadways between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day
without proper authorization from the Recreation Director, unless there is an
officially scheduled function of the City.
( Ord. 2000-5.  Passed 2-8-00. )
   151.10  USE OF SOFTBALL FIELD IN ELMWOOD PARK AND MUNICIPAL RECREATION
CENTER.
   The regulation softball field in the Elmwood Park and Municipal Recreation
Center shall be used only by residents of the City and their guests.
(Ord. 1986-13.  Passed 7-4-86; Res. 1989-41.  Passed 8-8-89.)
   151.11  CIVIC CENTER/RECREATION DEPARTMENT CHANGE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established a change fund out of the
general fund of the City in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for use
at the Civic Center/Recreation Department.
   (b)   Such change fund shall be maintained at the Civic Center/Recreation
Department and the Finance Director is authorized to replenish such fund upon
request and to account for transfers into and expenditures out of such fund.
(Ord.  2002-25.  Passed 5-14-02.)
   151.12  COMMUNITY SERVICES DEPARTMENT CHANGE FUND.

at the Community Services Department.
(Ord. 2006-57.  Passed 11-14-06.)
   (b)   Such change fund shall be maintained at the Community Services
Department and the Finance Director is authorized to replenish such fund upon

   151.13  CHANGE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established a change fund out of the

   (b)   Such change fund shall be maintained at the Elmwood Park Pool Front
Desk and the Finance Director is authorized to replenish such fund upon request

   151.16  SHARED USE FACILITY FIELD HOUSE AND COMMUNITY ROOMS CHANGE FUND.

Use Facility for the Field House and Community Rooms.  The Finance Director is
authorized to replenish such fund upon request and to account for transfers
into and expenditures out of such fund.
(Ord. 2006-59.  Passed 11-14-06.)
   151.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
151.09 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both. Whoever violates Section
151.10 is, for a first offense, guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be
fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Upon any subsequent
violation of any of the provisions of Section
151.10, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be
fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than
sixty days, or both.
(Ord. 1982-42. Passed 10-12-82.)

CHAPTER 154
Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund Board
154.01   Establishment.
154.02   Composition; vacancies.
154.03   Election and term of members.
154.04   Organization; rules and regulations.
154.05   Compensation and expenses of Board members.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 146
   Public meetings - see ADM. Ch.
105
   Fire Department - see ADM. Ch.
143
 
   154.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   To carry out the responsibilities and duties set forth in Ohio R.C. Chapter
146, a Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund Board is hereby established.
(Ord. 1976-39. Passed 9-14-76.)
   154.02  COMPOSITION; VACANCIES.
   (a)    The Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund Board shall be composed of
five members chosen as follows:
      (1)    Two members elected by Council;
      (2)    Two members elected by the Volunteer Firemen; and
      (3)    One member elected by the Board members referred to in subsections
(1) and (2) hereof. Such member shall be an elector of the City but he shall
not be an employee of the City, a member of Council or a regular or volunteer
member of the Fire Department.
   (b)    Vacancies occurring on the Board shall be filled as provided in
subsection (a) hereof for original appointments.
(Ord. 1976-39. Passed 9-14-76. )
   154.03  ELECTION AND TERM OF MEMBERS.
   (a)    The term of each member of the Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund
Board shall be for one year beginning on January 1 of each year.
   (b)    Elections for the Board members provided for in Section
154.02(a)(1) and (2) shall be held each year on the first Monday in December,
and the election for the Board member provided for in Section
154.02(a)(3) shall be held on or before the second Monday in December of each
year.
   (c)    Elections for the Board member provided for in Section
154.02(a)(2) shall be conducted as follows:
      (1)    The Secretary of the Board shall give notice of the election by
posting it in a conspicuous place in the Fire Department. Between 9:00 a.m. and
9:00 p.m. on the day designated, each member of the Volunteer Fire Department
shall submit in writing the names of two persons who are his choices. Such
persons shall be members of the Volunteer Fire Department.
      (2)    All votes cast at the election shall be counted and recorded by
the Board, which shall announce the results. The two members receiving the
highest number of votes shall be elected. If two persons receive a tie vote, it
shall be decided by lot or by any other way agreed upon by the persons for whom
such tie vote was cast.
         (Ord. 1976-39. Passed 9-14-76.)
   154.04  ORGANIZATION; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund Board shall meet promptly after its
election and organize. A Chairman and Secretary shall be elected. The Secretary
shall keep a complete record of the proceedings of the Board, which records
shall be maintained as a permanent file. The Board shall make rules and
regulations necessary for the handling and processing of claims and shall
perform such other duties as are necessary to carry out the provisions of Ohio
R.C. 146.01 through 146.19.
(Ord. 1976-39. Passed 9-14-76.)
   154.05  COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES OF BOARD MEMBERS.
   The members of the Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund Board shall serve
without compensation. The City shall provide the Board with a meeting place and
with the necessary stationery, postage and supplies for the conduct of the
Board's business.
(Ord. 1976-39. Passed 9-14-76.)
CHAPTER 155
Conflict of Interest
155.01   Conflict of interest.
155.02   Former officers or employees.
155.03   Unlawful interest in public contracts.
155.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Purchasing and contracts - see CHTR.,
Art. IV , Sec. (c)(5)
   Contract interest - see CHTR.,
Art. VI
 
   155.01  CONFLICT OF INTEREST . 
   No officer, member of Council or employee of the City shall: 
   (a)    Engage in the practice of law or represent or appear on behalf of an
individual before the Mayor's Court, the Municipal Court of Garfield Heights,
or any other court, in any matter or controversy in which the City is or may
become a party, except on behalf of the City as an officer or employee, or
volunteer opinion evidence against the interests of the City in any litigation
in which the City is a party; or 
   (b)    Appear before any board or commission of the City as counsel,
attorney or agent, except in the performance of public obligations or official
duties.
      (Ord. 1984-29. Passed 9-11-84.) 
   155.02  FORMER OFFICERS OR EMPLOYEES. 
   No person within a period of one year after termination of his services as
an officer or employee of the City shall appear before any board or commission
of the City as counsel, attorney or agent for or in behalf of any person, firm
or corporation, or receive compensation for any services rendered thereto, in
relation to any matter which was under his charge during the period of his
services as such officer or employee. 
   No person after termination of his services as an officer or employee of the
City shall accept compensation or employment in any matter which he has
investigated or passed upon while in such office or employ, or be involved in
any litigation in which the City is a party involving any such matter, except
in behalf of the City.
(Ord. 1965-10. Passed 2-23-65.) 
   155.03  UNLAWFUL INTEREST IN PUBLIC CONTRACTS.
   (a)    No public official shall knowingly do any of the following:
      (1)    During his term of office or within one year thereafter, occupy
any position of profit in the prosecution of a public contract authorized by
him or by a legislative body, commission or board of which he was a member at
the time of authorization unless the contract was let by competitive bidding,
to the lowest and best bidder;
      (2)    Have an interest in the profits or benefits of a public contract
entered into by or for the use of the Municipality or governmental agency or
instrumentality with which he is connected;
      (3)    Have an interest in the profits or benefits of a public contract
which is not let by competitive bidding when required by law, and which
involves more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
   (b)    In the absence of bribery or a purpose to defraud, a public servant,
member of his family or any of his associates shall not be considered as having
an interest in a public contract when all of the following apply:
      (1)    The interest of such person is limited to owning or controlling
shares of the corporation, or being a creditor of the corporation or other
organization, which is the contractor on the public contract involved, or which
is the issuer of the security in which public funds are invested;
      (2)    The shares owned or controlled by such person do not exceed five
percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation, and the amount due such
person as creditor does not exceed five percent of the total indebtedness of
the corporation or other organization;
      (3)    Such person, prior to the time the public contract is entered
into, files with the Municipality or governmental agency or instrumentality
involved, an affidavit giving his exact status in connection with the
corporation or other organization.
   (c)    This section does not apply to a public contract in which a public
servant, member of his family, or one of his business associates, has an
interest, when all of the following apply:
      (1)    The subject of the public contract is necessary supplies or
services for the Municipality or governmental agency or instrumentality
involved;
      (2)    The supplies or services are unobtainable elsewhere for the same
or lower cost, or are being furnished to the Municipality or governmental
agency or instrumentality as part of a continuing course of dealing established
prior to the public servant's becoming associated with the Municipality or
governmental agency or instrumentality involved;
      (3)    The treatment accorded the Municipality or governmental agency or
instrumentality is either preferential to or the same as that accorded other
customers or clients in similar transactions;
      (4)    The entire transaction is conducted at arm's length, with full
knowledge by the Municipality or governmental agency or instrumentality
involved, of the interest of the public servant, and the public servant takes
no part in the deliberations or decision of the Municipality or governmental
agency or instrumentality with respect to the public contract.
   (d)    Whoever violates this section is guilty of having an unlawful
interest in a public contract. Violation of this section is a misdemeanor of
the first degree. 
   (e)    It is not a violation of this section for a prosecuting attorney to
appoint assistants and employees in accordance with Ohio R.C. 309.06 or for a
chief legal officer of a municipal corporation or an official designated as
prosecutor in a municipal corporation to appoint assistants and employees in
accordance with Ohio R.C. 733.621. 
   (f)    As used in this section: 
      (1)    "Public contract" means any of the following: 
         A.    The purchase or acquisition, or a contract for the purchase or
acquisition of property or services by or for the use of the State or any of
its political subdivisions, or any agency or instrumentality of either. 
         B.    A contract for the design, construction, alteration, repair or
maintenance of any public property. 
       (2)    "Chief legal officer" has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C.
733.621. (ORC 2921.42) 
   155.99  PENALTY. 
   (a)    Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both, for each
offense. 
   (b)    The penalty provided for in subsection (a) hereof is in addition to
any other penalty provided by law.
(Ord. 1984-29. Passed 9-11-84.) 
CHAPTER 156
Master Cable Television Regulatory Ordinance
156.01   Intent.
156.02   Definitions.
156.03   Franchise to install operate.
156.04   Franchise required.
156.05   Term of the franchise.
156.06   Franchise territory.
156.07   Federal, State and City jurisdiction.
156.08   Franchise nontransferable.
156.09   Purchase by City.
156.10   Geographical coverage.
156.11   Nonexclusive franchise.
156.12   Multiple franchises.
156.13   Initial franchise or renewal applications.
156.14   Consideration of initial applications.
156.15   Franchise renewal.
156.16   Consumer protection and service standards.
156.17   Rate regulation; senior citizen discounts; promotions; broadcast
   basic service; guaranteed service calls.

   improvements.
156.20   Technical standards; tests.

   facilities.

156.27   Institutional network; interconnection with other government networks.

   facilities; fee in lieu.
156.29   Franchise violation.
156.30   Force majeure; grantee’s inability to perform.
156.31   Abandonment or removal of franchise property.
156.32   Extended operation and continuity of service.
156.33   Receivership and foreclosure.
156.34   Rights reserved to grantor.
156.35   Rights of individuals.
156.36   Time limits strictly construed.
156.37   Delegation of authority.
156.38   Conflicts.
156.39   Severability.
156.40   Customer service standards for the cable television system.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Telecommunication right-of-way permits - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
922
 
   156.01  INTENT.
   (a)   The City of Independence pursuant to applicable federal and State law,
is authorized to grant one or more nonexclusive Franchises to construct,
own,operate, maintain and reconstruct Cable Television Systems within the City
limits.
   (b)   The City Council finds that the development of Cable Television
Systems has the potential of having great benefit and impact upon the residents
of Independence.
   Because of the complex and rapidly changing technology associated with cable
television, the City Council further finds that the public convenience, safety
and general welfare can best be served by establishing, to the extent permitted
by state and federal law, regulatory powers which should be vested in the City
or such Persons as the City shall designate.  It is the intent of this chapter
and subsequent amendments to provide for and specify the means to attain the
best possible cable television service to the public and any Franchises issued
pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed to include this finding as an integral
part thereof.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein.  Words used in the
present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the
singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. 
All capitalized terms used in the definition of any other term shall have their
meaning as otherwise defined in this Section
156.02.  The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and "may" is permissive. 
Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning.
   (a)   "Basic Cable Service" means any service tier which includes the
retransmission of local television broadcast signals. (See 47 U.S.C. § 522(3))
"Expanded Basic" shall include all level or tiers of Cable Service exclusive of
premium and pay-per-view  and a la carte services or as otherwise defined by
Federal law or regulation.
   (b)   "Cable Act" means the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47
U.S.C. §§ 521-611 (1982 & Supp. V 1987), as amended by the Cable Television
Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992.  Pub. L. No. 102-385, and the
Telecommunications Act of 1996 and as may, from time to time, be amended.
   (c)   "Cable Television System", "System" or "Cable System" means a
facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated
signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide
Cable Service which includes video programming and which is provided to
multiple Subscribers within a community, but such term does not include:
      (1)   A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of
one (1) or more television broadcast stations;
      (2)   A facility that serves Subscribers without using any public rights-
of-way;
      (3)   A facility of a common carrier that is subject, in whole or in
part, to the provisions of 47 U.S.C. §§ 201-226, except that such facility
shall be considered a Cable System to the extent that such facility whether on
a common carrier basis or otherwise is used in the transmission of video
programming directly to Subscribers; or
      (4)   Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating
its electric utility System.  (See 47 U.S.C. § 522(7))
   (d)   "Cable Service" means:
      (1)   The one-way transmission to Subscribers of video programming or
other programming service; and
      (2)   Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection
or use of such video programming or other programming service.
         (See 47 U.S.C. § 522(6))
   (e)   "Channel" or "Cable Channel" means a portion of the electromagnetic
frequency spectrum that is used in a Cable System and which is capable of
delivering a television Channel as defined by the Federal Communications
Commission of FCC.  (See 47 U.S.C. § 522(4))
   (f)   "Council" means the City Council of the City of Independence.
   (g)   "Franchise" means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued
by the City, whether such authorization is designated as a Franchise, permit,
license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement, or otherwise, which
authorizes the construction and/or operation of a Cable System.  (See 47 U.S.C.
§ 522(g))
   (h)   "Franchise Agreement" means a Franchise granted pursuant to this
chapter, containing the specific provisions of the Franchise granted, including
references, specifications, requirements and other related matters.
   (i)   "Franchise Fee" means any tax, fee or assessment of any kind imposed
by the City or other governmental entity on a Grantee or cable Subscriber, or
both, solely because of their status as such.  The term "Franchise Fee" does
not include:
      (1)   any tax, fee, or assessment of general applicability (including any
such tax, fee, or assessment imposed on both utilities and cable operators or
their services but not including a tax, fee, or assessment which is unduly
discriminatory against cable operators or cable Subscribers);
      (2)   capital costs that are required by the Franchise Agreement to be
incurred by the cable operator for Public, Educational, or Governmental (PEG)
Access Facilities;
      (3)   requirements or charges incidental to the awarding or enforcing of
the Franchise, including payments for bonds, security funds, letters of credit,
insurance, indemnification, penalties, or liquidated damages; or
      (4)   any fee imposed under Title 17 of the United States Code.
         (See 47 U.S.C. § 522(g) )
   (j)   "Grantee" means any Person receiving a Franchise pursuant to this
chapter and its agents, employees, officers, designees, or any lawful
successor, transferee or assignee.
   (k)   "Grantor" or "City" means the City of Independence, as represented by
the Council or any delegate acting within the scope of its jurisdiction.
   (l)   "Gross Revenues" means all amounts earned by the Grantee,  in whatever
form and from all sources, derived from the provision of video programming
services and advertising distributed by Grantee over Grantee's Cable System
within the City and converter equipment rentals and installation.  Gross
Revenues shall include, without limitation, amounts received from Subscribers
for all video programming services, including but not limited to premium
service, pay-per-view service, basic service, expanded basic service, converter
equipment rentals and installation, advertising and all other revenues derived
from the provision of video programming services, advertising, converter
equipment rentals and installations.  "Gross revenues" shall also include
amounts earned during any period for the provision of Cable Service regardless
of whether: (1)the amounts are paid in cash, in trade, or by means of some
other benefit to the Grantee;  (2)the goods or services with which the revenue
is associated are provided at cost or the revenue amount can be matched against
an equivalent expenditure; (3)the amounts are characterized, separately
identified or accounted for as being for goods, services, or fees to be paid
for government agencies; and (4)the amounts are initially recorded by the
Grantee or any affiliated entity. 
      Notwithstanding the above and in accordance with generally accepted
accounting practices, "Gross Revenue" shall not include: (1)revenues of  any
affiliated entity to the extent that such revenues have also been reported as
revenues by Grantee; (2)revenues from the sale of goods and merchandise to the
extent that Grantee does not retain the revenue collected; (3)revenues from
capital contributions paid by commercial entities to extend Cable System plant
so as to serve such commercial location and revenues collected from subscribers
as capital contributions in order to meet identified cable-related needs of the
City; (4)any amounts documented as bad debt or refunds to Subscribers; and
(5)any copyright fees.
   (m)   "Initial Service Area" means the area of the City that will receive
Cable Service initially, as set forth in any Franchise Agreement.
   (n)   "Installation" means the connection of the System to Subscribers'
terminals, and the provision of Cable Service.
   (o)   "Material" means having real importance or significant substance or
consequence.
   (p)   "Normal Business Hours" means those hours during which most similar
businesses in the community are open to serve customers.  In all cases, "Normal
Business Hours" must include some evening hours at least one (1) night per week
and/or some weekend hours.
   (q)   "Normal Operating Conditions" means those service conditions that are
within the control of the Grantee.  Those conditions that are not within the
control of the Grantee which include, but are not limited to, natural
disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, work
stoppages, and severe or unusual weather conditions, and significant
legislative or regulatory requirements.  Those conditions which are ordinarily
within the control of the Grantee include, but are not limited to, special
promotions, pay-per-view events, regular peak or seasonal demand periods, and
maintenance or upgrade of the System.
   (r)   "Notice" shall mean written notice to the address indicated in the
Franchise Agreement.
   (s)   "Opportunity to Cure" or "Opportunity to Correct" shall mean ten (10)
calendar days unless some other time period is contained herein or is agreed to
between Grantor and Grantee.
   (t)   "Other programming service" means information that a Cable Operator
makes available to all subscribers generally.  (See 47 U.S.C. § 522(15))
   (u)   "Person" means any natural Person or any association, firm,
individual, partnership, joint stock company, joint venture, trust,
corporation, limited liability company or other legally recognized entity,
private or public, whether for-profit or not-for-profit.
   (v)   "Public, Educational or Government Access Facilities" or "PEG Access
Facilities" means:
      (1)   Channel capacity designated for public, educational, or
governmental use; and
      (2)   Facilities and equipment for the use of such Channel capacity.
   (w)   "Reasonable" means neither extreme, excessive, arbitrary, capricious,
oppressive and not confiscatory under the particular circumstances at issue.
   (x)   "Section" means any Section, subsection, or provision of this chapter.
   (y)   "Service Area" or "Franchise Area" means the entire geographic area
within the City as it is now constituted or may in the future be constituted,
unless otherwise specified in the Franchise Agreement.
   (z)   "Service Interruption" means the loss of picture or sound on one or
more Cable Channels affecting at least ten percent (10%) of the Subscribers on
the System.
   (aa)   "Standard Installation" means cable connections consisting of no less
than a 125 foot drop from the nearest street containing utility distribution
facilities connecting to an inside wall for residential subscribers and a 125
foot drop for commercial subscribers and shall not mean inside "wall fish"
installations, or buried installations where adverse terrain (such as excessive
rocky conditions) or other factors render extension of the system economically
or technically more expensive or difficult than typically encountered by
Grantee in its normal operations.  The 125 foot drop shall be determined by the
measurement from the property line to  the point of initial contact on the
building.
   (bb)   "State" means the State of Ohio.
   (cc)   "Street" means each of the following that have been dedicated to the
public or are hereafter dedicated to the public and maintained under public
authority or by others and located within the City limits:  Streets, roadways,
highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way and
similar public property and areas that the Grantor shall permit to be included
within the definition of Street from time to time.
   (dd)   "Subscriber" means any Person who or which lawfully elects to
subscribe to, for any purpose, Cable Service provided by the Grantee by means
of or in connection with the Cable System and who pays the charges therefor,
except such Persons or entities authorized to receive Cable Service without
charge as described in the Franchise Agreement.
      (Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.03  FRANCHISE TO INSTALL AND OPERATE.
   A Franchise granted by the City under the provisions of this chapter shall
encompass the following purposes:
   (a)   To engage in the business of providing Cable Service, and such other
services as may be permitted by the Franchise Agreement.
   (b)   To erect, own, install, construct, repair, rebuild, reconstruct,
replace, maintain and retain, cable lines, related electronic equipment,
supporting structures, appurtenances, and other property in connection with the
operation of a Cable System in, on, over, under, upon, along and across Streets
or other public places within the designated Service Area.
   (c)   To maintain and operate said Franchise properties for the origination,
reception, transmission, amplification, and distribution of television and
radio signals for the delivery of Cable Services and any other services
permitted by the Franchise Agreement.
   (d)   To set forth the obligations of a Grantee under the Franchise
Agreement.
      (Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.04  FRANCHISE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any Person to construct, install or operate a Cable
Television System in the City within any Street without a properly granted
Franchise awarded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.05  TERM OF THE FRANCHISE.
   (a)   A Franchise granted hereunder shall be for a term established in the
Franchise Agreement, commencing on the effective date of an ordinance or
resolution authorizing the Franchise.
   (b)   A Franchise granted hereunder may be renewed upon application by the
Grantee pursuant to the provisions of applicable State and federal law and of
this chapter.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.06  FRANCHISE TERRITORY.
   Any Franchise shall be valid within all the territorial limits of the City,
and within any area added to the City during the term of the Franchise, unless
otherwise specified in the Franchise Agreement.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.07  FEDERAL, STATE AND CITY JURISDICTION.
   (a)   This chapter shall be construed in a manner consistent with all
applicable federal and State laws.
   (b)   In the event that the State or federal government discontinues
preemption in any area of cable communications over which it currently
exercises jurisdiction in such manner as to expand rather than limit municipal
regulatory authority, Grantor may, if it so elects, adopt rules and regulations
in these areas to the extent permitted by law.  Grantor shall notify Grantees
of its intent to adopt rules and regulations in writing at least thirty (30)
days prior to the adoption of the rules and regulations.
   (c)   This chapter shall apply to all Franchises granted or renewed after
the effective date of this chapter.
   (d)   Grantee's rights are subject to the police powers of the City to adopt
and enforce ordinances necessary to the health, safety and welfare of the
public.  Grantee shall comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances
enacted, or hereafter enacted, by the City pursuant to that power or any other
legally constituted governmental unit having lawful jurisdiction over the
subject matter hereof.
   (e)   Grantee shall not be relieved of its obligation to comply with any of
the provisions of this chapter or any Franchise granted pursuant to this
chapter by reason of any failure of the City to enforce prompt compliance.
   (f)   This chapter and any Franchise granted pursuant to this chapter shall
be construed and enforced in accordance with the substantive laws of the State
of Ohio.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.08  FRANCHISE NONTRANSFERABLE.
   (a)   Grantee shall not sell, transfer, lease, assign, sublet or dispose of,
in whole or in part, either by forced or involuntary sale, or by ordinary sale,
consolidation or otherwise, the Franchise and/or Cable System or any of the
rights or privileges granted by the Franchise, without the prior consent of the
Council which consent shall not be unreasonably denied or delayed and shall be
denied only upon a good faith finding by the City that the proposed transferee
lacks the legal, technical or financial qualifications to perform its
obligations under the Franchise Agreement, and then only upon such reasonable
terms and conditions as the Grantor may require.  Any attempt to sell,
transfer, lease, assign or otherwise dispose of the Franchise and/or Cable
System without the consent of the Council shall be null and void.  This
provision shall not apply to sales of property or equipment in the normal
course of business.  No consent from the City shall be required for a transfer
in trust, mortgage, or other instrument of hypothecation, in whole or in part,
to secure an indebtedness, or for a pro forma transfer to a corporation,
partnership or other entity controlling, controlled by or under common control
with Grantee.
   (b)   The following events shall be deemed to be a sale, assignment or other
transfer of the Franchise and/or Cable System requiring compliance with this
Section:
      (1)   The sale, assignment or other transfer of all or a majority of
Grantee's assets;
      (2)   The sale, assignment or other transfer of capital stock or
partnership, membership or other equity interests in Grantee by one or more of
its existing shareholders, partners, members or other equity owners so as to
create a new controlling interest in Grantee;
      (3)   The issuance of additional capital stock or partnership, membership
or other equity interest by Grantee so as to create a new controlling interest
in Grantee; and
      (4)   The entry by the Grantee into an agreement with respect to the
management or operation of the Grantee and/or the System.
   The term "Controlling Interest" as used herein means majority equity
ownership of the Grantee.
   (c)   Except as otherwise provided below or unless waived by Grantor as
provided under Section
156.34 herein, no Grantee may sell or otherwise transfer ownership in a
Franchise and/or Cable System prior to the substantial completion of the
initial design or initial construction of said System by Grantee.  In the case
of a sale of multiple Systems, if the terms of the sale require the buyer to
subsequently transfer ownership of one or more such Systems to one or more
third parties, such transfer shall be considered a part of the initial
transaction.  The above-described holding period shall not apply to:
      (1)   Any transfer of ownership interest in any Franchise and/or Cable
System which is not subject to federal income tax liability;
      (2)   Any sale required by operation of any law or any act of any agency,
any State or political subdivision or the City; or
      (3)   Any sale, assignment, or transfer, to one or more purchasers,
assignees, or transferees controlled by, controlling, or under common control
with, the seller, assignor, or transferor or its affiliate.
   (d)   In the case of any sale or transfer of ownership of any Franchise and/
or Cable System, the City shall have one hundred twenty (120) days to act upon
any request for approval of such sale or transfer that contains or is
accompanied by such information as is required in accordance with Federal
Communications Commission Regulations, the requirements of this chapter and
such other reasonable information as the City, in its sole discretion, may
request. 
   During the review period, the Grantor may advise the Grantee that a public
hearing is deemed necessary to evaluate any potential adverse effect of the
sale or transfer upon Grantee's subscribers.  In such event Grantee shall
receive written notice of the hearing, and of the opportunity to participate
fully in it, as far in advance as possible, and in no event less than fourteen
(14) days prior to the start of the hearing.  If the City fails to render a
final decision on the request within one hundred twenty (120) days from receipt
by the City of all required information, such request shall be deemed granted
unless the requesting party and the City agree to an extension of time.  Such
request to transfer may be conditioned upon the performance of additional
requirements imposed upon Grantee by Grantor, and the payment of a
nonrefundable transfer fee of five thousand dollars ($5,000).
   (e)   Grantee shall notify Grantor in writing of any foreclosure or any
other judicial sale of all or a substantial part of the Franchise property of
the Grantee or upon the termination of any lease or interest covering all or a
substantial part of said Franchise property. Such notification shall be
considered by Grantor as notice that a change in control or ownership of the
Franchise has taken place and the provisions under this Section governing the
consent of Grantor to such change in control or ownership shall apply.
   (f)   For the purpose of determining whether it shall consent to such
change, transfer, or acquisition of control, Grantor may inquire into the
qualifications of the prospective transferee or controlling party, and Grantee
shall assist Grantor in any such inquiry.  In seeking Grantor's consent to any
change of ownership or control, Grantee shall have the responsibility of
insuring that the transferee completes an application in form and substance
reasonably satisfactory to Grantor, which application shall include the
information required under State and federal law as well as under subsections
(b) (1)through (7) of Section156.13.  An application, acceptable to the City,
shall be submitted to Grantor not less than ninety (90) days prior to the date
of transfer.  The transferee shall be required to establish that it possesses
the legal, technical and financial qualifications to operate and maintain the
System and comply with all Franchise requirements for the remainder of the term
of the Franchise.  If, after considering the legal, financial, character and
technical qualities of the applicant and determining that they are
satisfactory, the Grantor finds that such transfer is acceptable, the Grantor
shall transfer and assign the rights and obligations of such Franchise.  The
consent of the Grantor to such transfer shall not be unreasonably denied.
   (g)   The consent or approval of the Grantor to transfer by the Grantee
shall not constitute a waiver or release of the rights of the Grantor in or to
its public rights-of-way or easements and any transfer shall by its own terms
be expressly subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter and the
Franchise Agreement.  A sale, transfer or assignment of the Franchise may not
be approved without the successor in interest becoming a signatory to the
Franchise Agreement.
   (h)   Any financial institution having a pledge of the Grantee or its assets
for the advancement of money for the construction and/or operation of the
Franchise shall have the right to notify the Grantor that it or its designee
satisfactory to the Grantor shall take control of and operate the Cable
Television System, in the event of a Grantee default in its financial
obligations.  Further, said financial institution shall also submit a plan for
such operation within thirty (30) days of assuming such control that will
insure continued service and compliance with all Franchise requirements during
the term the financial institution exercises control over the System.  The
financial institution shall not exercise control over the System for a period
exceeding one (1) year unless extended by the Grantor in its discretion and
during said period of time it shall have the right to petition the Grantor to
transfer the Franchise to another Grantee.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.09  PURCHASE BY CITY.
   (a)    Grantor may, at any time, offer to purchase Grantee's Cable System
for the same consideration and other terms it is willing to accept from any
person.  The Grantee shall have 30 days from receipt of the offer from Grantor
within which to accept the offer.
   (b)    In any case where the Grantor elects to purchase the System, the
purchase shall be closed within 60 days of the date of Grantor's audit of a
current profit and loss statement of the Grantee.
(Ord. 1997-25. Passed 12-9-97.)
   156.10  GEOGRAPHICAL COVERAGE.
   (a)   Grantee shall design, construct and maintain the Cable Television
System to have the capability to pass every dwelling unit, school, library, and
municipal building in the Service Area, subject to any line extension
requirements of the Franchise Agreement.
   (b)   After service has been established by activating trunk and/or
distribution cables for any part of the Service Area, Grantee shall provide
Cable Service to any non-commercial Subscriber requesting a standard
installation within that part of the Service Area within seven (7) days from
the date of request if no further construction is required or within thirty
(30) days if construction is required, provided that the Grantee is able to
secure all rights-of-way necessary to extend service to such Subscriber on
reasonable terms and conditions within such thirty (30) day period.  For
purposes of this Section, a request shall be deemed made on the date of signing
a service agreement, receipt of funds by the Grantee, receipt of a written
request by the Grantee or receipt by the Grantee of a verified verbal request.
   (c)   Except as otherwise provided in the Franchise Agreement, Grantee shall
provide such service:
      (1)    With no line extension charge except as specifically authorized in
the Franchise Agreement.
      (2)    At a non-discriminatory installation charge for a Standard
Installation, with additional charges for non-standard installations computed
according to a non-discriminatory methodology for such installations, adopted
by the Grantee.
      (3)    At non-discriminatory monthly rates for residential subscribers;
      (4)    Grantee may establish different and nondiscriminatory rates and
charges of services for commercial subscribers, as well as different,
