CHAPTER 771
Retail Dry Cleaning Establishments
771.01   License required; fee.   
771.02   Hours; attendant required.
771.03   Safety provisions.
771.04   Liability insurance required.
771.05   Inspector of Buildings regulations.
771.06   Revocation of license.
771.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCE
   Dry cleaning and dyeing - see Ohio R. C. Ch. 3739
 
   771.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE .
   No person shall use any premises for or operate a retail dry cleaning
establishment unless a license has first been obtained from the Inspector of
Buildings. No such license shall be issued until the applicant therefor has
submitted detailed plans indicating the layout of installation of equipment and
appurtenances, until the ten dollar ($10.00) fee for such license has been
paid, and unless the plans comply with all applicable provisions of the
Building Code and of the State, the requirements of this chapter and any
regulations promulgated by the Inspector pursuant thereto.
   Such license shall be renewed on or before January 1 of each year according
to the provisions of Ohio R. C. 3739.07.
   771.02 HOURS; ATTENDANT REQUIRED.
   No retail dry cleaning establishment shall be open for customers later than
11:00 p.m. No retail dry cleaning establishment, whether automatic or coin
operated, or otherwise, shall be operated without an attendant on duty at all
times that the store is open.
(Ord. 1962-6. Passed 3-13-62.)
   771.03 SAFETY PROVISIONS.
   All dry cleaning establishments shall be located in single-story buildings
and no part of such buildings shall be used for residential purposes.
   The cleaning solvent used shall be nonflammable, and no open-flame burning
equipment shall be permitted within the building. Suitable provisions shall be
made for the control of the liquid and the prevention of fumes in the area open
to the public.
   Coin-operated machines shall be designed to prevent the opening of the
loading door in the event of power failure, and to prevent the interruption of
the cleaning cycle or the removal of solvent-laden garments. Exhaust ducts and
stacks and fresh air supply shall be installed so as to guarantee the
protection of the public. All machines and equipment shall be kept clean and in
repair, and shall be subject to inspection by the Inspector of Buildings.
Safety regulations and instructions to customers, approved by the Inspector,
shall be posted in the customer area. (Ord. 1962-6. Passed 3-13-62. )
   771.04 LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   Every operator of a retail dry cleaning establishment shall provide evidence
to the Inspector of Buildings of satisfactory liability insurance coverage in
the amounts of one hundred thousand dollars/three hundred thousand dollars
($100,000/$300,000) for personal injury or death, and twenty thousand dollars
($20,000) for property damage.
(Ord. 1962-6. Passed 3-13-62. )
   771.05 INSPECTOR OF BUILDINGS REGULATIONS.
   The Inspector of Buildings shall promulgate rules and regulations for the
protection of the public, applicable to the operation of retail dry cleaning
establishments, in conformity with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1962-6. Passed 3-13-62. )
   771.06 REVOCATION OF LICENSE .
   The Inspector of Buildings may revoke the license of any operator of a
retail dry cleaning establishment, or may refuse to renew such license for the
failure to comply in every respect with all provisions of this chapter or other
ordinances of the City, laws of the State or regulations promulgated pursuant
hereto.
(Ord. 1962-6. Passed 3-13-62. )
   771.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
two hundred dollars ($200.00). Every day's continued violation shall constitute
a separate offense. (Ord. 1962-6. Passed 3-13-62.)
 
CHAPTER 773
Child Day-Care Homes
773.01    Purpose.
773.02    Definitions.
773.03    Exemptions.
773.04    Permit application, issuance, term, renewal and fee.
773.05    Prohibitions.
773.06    Provider qualifications.
773.07    General standards.
773.08    Permit refusal, suspension or revocation.
773.09    Fire Department inspection.
773.10   Safety and supervision of children requirements.
773.11    Medication administration requirements.
773.12    Records requirements.
773.13    Transportation.
773.14    Insurance.
773.15    Non-liability of City; parental responsibility; public record.
773.99    Penalty.
   773.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Chapter
773 is to provide for the licensing through permit of child day-care homes and
establish minimum fire safety and health standards for child day-care homes. It
is anticipated that the inspection for compliance with the standards set forth
herein will be made by the Fire Chief, the Chief of Police, and/or any other
person or department that the Mayor may designate.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this Chapter:
   "Child Day-Care Home" means the personal residence of the provider, other
than the child's own home, in which child day-care is provided at any one time
for three (3), four (4), five (5), or six (6) children and in which no more
than three (3) children may be under two (2) years of age at one time for any
child day-care exceeding ten days in any calender year. In counting children
for the purposes of this division, any children under six (6) years of age who
are related by blood or marriage to the provider and who are on the premises of
the child day-care home shall be counted. 
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.03 EXEMPTIONS.
   This Chapter
773 shall not apply:
   (a)   To care provided by a person who is related by blood or marriage to
the child or children, if more than one, being cared for;
   (b)   To child care services provided less than four (4) consecutive hours
in any twenty-four (24) hour period; and
   (c)   To a child day-care center, and in-home aid, a type A family day-care
home, a type A home, and/or a certified type B family day-care home as defined
in Revised Code §5104.01.
      (Ord.  2002-46.  Passed 7-30-02.)
   773.04 PERMIT APPLICATION, ISSUANCE, TERM, RENEWAL AND FEE.
   (a)   Every person who operates or desires to establish a child day-care
home shall apply to The Mayor or to his representative for a permit on such
form as he prescribes and as approved by Council. The permit shall be renewed
annually, and a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) shall be paid for each
permit or renewal thereof. Fees collected under this Section shall be paid into
the City's General Fund.
   (b)   Upon filing, the application shall be forwarded to the Zoning
Administrator for review, the Police Department for completion of background
check to the Fire Department for inspection of the premises under Ohio Fire
Code, Life Safety Code and Existing Structure Code including this Chapter
773 and all other Codes of the City of Independence. When, after the provisions
set forth in this Chapter have been completed, and the Mayor or his
representative is satisfied that all requirements are complied with, a permit
shall be issued in such form and manner as he prescribes but including at least
the name of the property owner and the name of the provider. The permit shall
be valid only for the provider at the address designated on the permit and the
permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the subject premises. The
permit shall not be transferable.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.05 PROHIBITIONS.
   No person, firm, or organization, institution or agency shall operate,
establish, manage, conduct or maintain a child day-care home in violation of
any of the provisions of this Chapter and without a valid permit issued
pursuant to this Chapter.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.06 PROVIDER QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)    The applicant and/or provider shall be at least eighteen (18) years
of age.
   (b)    The applicant must present satisfactory evidence of personal
residence in the dwelling to be used as child day-care home.
   (c)    The provider shall be examined by a licensed physician or certified
nurse practitioner not more than six months prior to submission of the permit
application, and shall provide a statement, signed by a licensed physician or 
certified nurse practitioner that states that the provider is free from any
communicable diseases or other condition that could affect his/her ability to
perform child care duties and which do not pose a serious threat to the well-
being of any child in his/her care.
   (d)   Upon issuance of child day-care home permit, the provider shall submit
a  new medical statement at least once every two (2) years. The medical
statement shall be confidential and shall not be a public record, unless
specifically required by law.
   (e)   The provider or any resident of the home shall not:
      (1)   Be under the influence of alcohol or other drugs while child care
is being provided.
      (2)   Have been convicted of or pleaded guilty to crimes or offenses
listed in Section 5104.012 of the Ohio Revised Code.
      (3)   Have been convicted of or pleaded guilty to crimes listed in
division (A)(1) of Section 5104.09 of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (f)   The provider and every individual eighteen (18) years of age or older
residing in the home shall sign a "Child Care Conviction Statement" attesting
that he has not been convicted of, or pleaded guilty to, any offense listed in
division (A)(1) of the Section of 5104.09 of the Ohio Revised Code and that no
child has been removed from his or her home pursuant to Section 2151.353 of the
Ohio Revised Code.
   (g)    The provider shall sign the "Child Care Conviction Statement"
attesting that no person who resides at the home and who is under the age of
eighteen (18) has been determined by the court to be delinquent child for
committing a violation of any provision listed in division (A)(1) of Section
5104.09 of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (h)    The provider shall have received training in first aid and
cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) appropriate to the age range of the
children in provider's care. The training shall be provided by an American Red
Cross and/or American Heart Association certified instructor. The provider
shall provide evidence of training upon initial application and upon each
renewal application.
   (i)   The provider shall have received training in the prevention,
recognition and management of communicable diseases from the American Red Cross
or other City approved certified agency or instructor. The provider shall
provide evidence of training upon initial application and upon each renewal
application.
   (j)   The provider shall disclose within the permit application and, in
writing, to the parent, guardian, custodian or other person responsible for the
care of the child the following information if applicable:
      (1)   That a child died while in the care of the provider or as a result
of injuries suffered while under the care of the provider; or
      (2)   That a child suffered injuries while under the care of the provider
that led to the child being hospitalized for more than twenty-four (24) hours.
   (k)   The provider shall provide proof of insurance as required by Section
773.13 below.
   (l)   The provider shall sign and agree to a criminal background check which
shall be performed by the City's Police Department.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.07 GENERAL STANDARDS.
   (a)    The provider shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age and have a
minimum of six (6) months experience in caring for children (either as a parent
or in another context including previous employment, center observations,
volunteer service, in-service training, etc.)
   (b)    The provider shall take preventative steps to ensure the safety of
the children in care. These steps must include: providing flashlights or other
emergency lighting, repair of loose floor boards, removal of peeling and/or
accessible lead paint, and removing sharp and dangerous objects.
   (c)    Firearms shall be unloaded and kept in a secure storage area and out
of
reach of the children.  (Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.08 PERMIT REFUSAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   The Mayor shall have the power to refuse issuance or suspend or revoke any
permit granted under the provisions of this Chapter if any of the following
conditions exist:
   (a)   If any false statement has been made by the provider in connection
with the application for the permit or in the operation pursuant to such
permit.
   (b)   If the provider fails or refuses to comply with any provisions of this
chapter or with any other City ordinances or state or federal laws applicable
thereto.
   (c)   If the building or premises for which the permit has been issued does
not comply with all provisions of this chapter and all other City ordinances
and state or federal laws applicable thereto.
      (Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.09 FIRE DEPARTMENT INSPECTION.
   (a)    The City Fire Department shall perform a safety inspection of the
child day-care home upon application by a provider. The City Fire Department
shall establish standard guidelines to be used in the child day-care home
safety inspection.
   (b)    Once a provider has been issued a permit, the City Fire Department
may randomly inspect a child day-care home during any of its hours of
operation.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.10 SAFETY AND SUPERVISION OF CHILDREN REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    The provider shall be responsible for the child's safety while child
care is being provided.
   (b)    No child shall ever be left unsupervised.
   (c)    When inside the home, all children in the provider's care shall be
within sight or hearing of the provider at all times.
   (d)    There shall be immediate access at all times to a working telephone
within the home.
   (e)   The provider shall have written permission from the parent before a
child is permitted to participate in swimming activities.
   (f)    The provider shall immediately notify either the City Police
Department or the Cuyahoga County Department of Children and Family Services,
when the provider suspects that a child has been abused or neglected.
   (g)   Emergency Caregivers.
      (1)   The permit holder shall provide the City and parents and/or
guardians of children in his/her care, with a list of at least two (2) persons
who shall serve as emergency caregivers.
      (2)   The emergency caregivers may provide child care services for a
maximum of one day due to an unplanned absence by the provider as a result of
unanticipated circumstances such as illness, accident or other family crisis.
      (3)   The emergency caregiver shall be eighteen (18) years old, but need
not meet the requirements set forth in Section
 773.06.
      (4)   The provider shall contact the parents or guardian immediately when
an emergency caregiver is used.
         (Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.11 MEDICATION ADMINISTRATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    A provider shall receive written consent from any child's parents
and/or guardians prior to administering any medication, whether oral or
topical, to that child and such written consent shall include, but is not
necessary limited to, the name of each medication the provider is permitted to
administer, the approved dosage, the time the medication may be administered,
the date the written consent is provided, and the signature of the child's
parents and/or guardians.
   (b)     In addition to the written consent from the child's parents and/or
guardians, in the form described in paragraph (a), to administer prescription
medication and nonprescription medication which contain codeine or aspirin to a
child, the provider must have a prescription label or written physician's
instructions for each medication, which shall include the child's name, the
current date, the name of medication, the number and amount of dosages to be
given and method of administration.
   (c)   The provider shall not administer a dosage which exceeds the
manufacturer's recommended dosage except with a written physician's
instruction.
   (d)   All written instructions or consents shall be valid for only six (6)
months unless a shorter time period is designated by the physician, dentist or
parent.
   (e)   Nonprescription and prescription medication shall be in the original
container  with the original label attached, and shall be marked with the
child's name.
   (f)   Medication shall be kept in a safe location where children cannot
reach it.
   (g)   The provider shall maintain a written record of the date, time and
amount of each medication given except for nonprescription topical ointments,
creams or lotions.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.12 RECORDS REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    The provider shall maintain an enrollment record on file for each
child in his/her care by the first day of attendance containing the following
information:
      (1)   The child's name, address, birth date, date of enrollment and the
first day of attendance.
      (2)   The names, addresses and telephone numbers of each parent.
      (3)   The name, telephone number and address of the place of employment
or location where the parent can be contacted each day the child is in care.
      (4)   The names, addresses, telephone numbers and relationships to each
child of at least two individuals who could be contacted in the event of an
emergency if the parent cannot be reached.
   (b)   Medical, Dental and Emergency Records.
      (1)   The permit holder must maintain a record of the following
information for each child in care:
         A.    A list of all allergies and any special precaution or treatment
indicated for these allergies.
         B.    A list of any medications currently being administered to the
child.
         C.    A list of any chronic physical problems and/or psychological
problems and any history of hospitalization.
         D.    A description of any modified dietary restrictions.
         E.    An Emergency Transportation Authorization record, including:
            1.   The child's name, address and telephone number.
            2.   The parent's work or school address and telephone number.
            3.   Name, addresses and telephone numbers of the child's physician
or clinic and dentist.
            4.   The names, addresses, telephone numbers and relationships to
the child of at least two persons who could be contacted by the provider in the
event of an emergency if the parent cannot be contacted.
            5.   The Emergency Transportation Authorization Record shall be
signed and dated by the parent, and shall either expressly grant consent to
transport the child to a designated source or sources of emergency medical or
dental treatment or expressly refuse to grant consent to transport the child to
a source of emergency treatments and shall include specific instructions to the
provider in the event of illness or injury requiring emergency medical or
dental treatment.
            6.   The provider shall send the child's health record information
with the child who is being transported to a source of emergency assistance.
            7.   The child's health record shall be confidential, except that
it may be disclosed to any emergency contact or designated or emergency health
care provider.
   (c)   Emergency telephone numbers for the emergency squad, fire department,
hospital, poison control center, children's protective services agency and
police department, or 911 shall be posted by a telephone that is accessible to
the provider and any other persons in the home.
   (d)   The provider shall file an injury/illness report with the Independence
Police Department when any of the following occur:
      (1)   A child is transported in accordance with this rule to a source of
emergency assistance.
      (2)   A child receives a bump or blow to the head.
      (3)   An unusual or unexpected incident occurs which jeopardizes the
safety of a child or staff, such as a child leaving the home unattended.
      (4)   A serious incident, injury or illness to a child. A serious
incident, injury or illness includes any situation that requires a child to be
removed from the home for medical treatment, professional consultation or
transported for emergency treatment.
   (e)   A copy of the injury/illness report shall be given to the child's
parent on the day of the incident/injury and kept on file in the provider's
home.
   (f)   All records required to be kept pursuant to this Chapter shall be
available for inspection by the Mayor or his designee.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.13 TRANSPORTATION.
   If the provider intends to transport children from the child day-care home,
by vehicle or otherwise, the provider shall inform the parents and/or guardians
of such children and shall obtain their written consent prior to transportation
of the child or children. In such event, the provider shall, at the time that
notice is provided pursuant to the preceding sentence, also provide the parents
or legal guardians with proof of insurance, license, and registration with
respect to the provider and/or the vehicle to be used in connection with such
transportation.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.14 INSURANCE.
   The provider of child day-care services shall obtain, and keep in force at
all times during which the provider holds a permit hereunder and provides child
day-care home services, a minimum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000)
of child care liability insurance (as a rider to the homeowner's policy or as a
separate policy). The provider shall promptly provide the City of Independence
with a certificate (or other proof) of insurance and all renewals thereof. 
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.15 NON-LIABILITY OF CITY; PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY; PUBLIC RECORD.
   (a)   The granting of child day-care home permit shall not constitute
directly or indirectly a recommendation as to suitability, or assumption of
responsibility for the quality of care, nor for any loss, injury or damage
which may arise out of or relate to the placement of any child with a child
day-care home provider, by the City or its officials, officers, employees, or
agents. The granting of a permit means that on the day the permit was issued,
the applicant met the requirements cited herein based upon the information then
available.
   (b)   It shall be the responsibility of the provider, parents and/or legal
guardians to monitor daily compliance with applicable regulations and to report
violations to the City Police Department, or Mayor for further investigation.
   (c)    All records pertaining to child day-care homes, except those
designated by this Chapter or otherwise by law, shall be available for public
inspection by any person during business hours of the City.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
   773.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    In addition to other remedies provided by law, and except as
otherwise provided herein, a violation of Section
773.05 by any person shall constitute a first degree misdemeanor. Each day a
violation occurs is deemed a separate offense.
   (b)   In addition to other remedies provided by law, a violation of Section
773.06(g) by any person shall constitute a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
   (c)   In addition to other remedies provided by law, any person found guilty
of knowingly making a materially false statement in applying for a permit under
this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord.  2002-22.  Passed 4-9-02.)
CHAPTER 775
Video Service Provider Fees
775.01   Fee established.
 
   775.01  FEE ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   In accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 1332.32, all video
service providers providing video service in the City pursuant to a video
service authorization obtained from the Director of the Ohio Department of
Commerce (“providers”) shall pay no video service provider fees (“VSP fees”),
totaling zero percent (0%) of gross revenues received from providing video
service in the City.
   (b)   Although the City will not charge a VSP fee to any providers, the City
hereby reserves its right to charge a VSP fee, not to exceed five percent (5%)
of gross revenues, in the future.
   (c)   If, at any time in the future, the City chooses to exercise its
reserved right to charge a VSP fee to providers, the City shall pass an
ordinance charging the VSP fee at a specified rate and shall provide written
notice to the providers, within reasonable time, regarding the same.
   (d)   As used in this section, “gross revenues” shall be defined by Ohio
R.C. 1332.32(B)(1) and shall include advertising revenues, as defined by Ohio
R.C. 1332.32(B)(2)(g).
   (e)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed, upon receipt of notice
from a provider that it intends to begin providing video service in the City,
to submit to such provider written notice of the City’s decision to not charge
VSP fees at this time, as determined by this section, which notice shall be
delivered in a manner that shows proof of timely delivery.
(Ord. 2008-04.  Passed 1-2-08.)
CHAPTER 781
Sale of Weapons
781.01   License to dispose of concealable weapons.
781.02   Application for license.
781.03   Daily report of sales.
781.04   Prohibition of sale.
781.05   Revocation of license.
781.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Carrying concealed weapon - see GEN. OFF.
672.02
   License to possess dangerous ordnance - see GEN. OFF.
672.07
   Sale of firearms and explosives to minors - see GEN. OFF.
672.10,
672.11
   Sale of fireworks - see GEN. OFF.
672.12
 
   781.01 LICENSE TO DISPOSE OF CONCEALABLE WEAPONS.
   No person shall engage in the business of selling within the City any
pistol, revolver, derringer, bowie knife, dirk or other weapon of like
character which can be concealed on the person without securing a license to do
so as hereinafter provided, and no person having secured such a permit, shall
sell or give away any such weapon except in strict accordance with all
Municipal, State and Federal laws pertaining to firearms.
(Ord. 1967-2. Passed 1-24-67.)
   781.02 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE .
   Any person desiring a license authorizing the sale of any of the weapons
mentioned in Section
781.01 shall make application in writing to the Chief of Police, setting out in
such application the full name and residence of the applicant, if an
individual, and if a firm or corporation the name and residence of each of its
members or officers. Such applicant shall also set out the location at which it
is intended or desired to conduct such business. Upon the receipt of such
application it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to issue a license at
no cost to the applicant. (Ord. 1967-2. Passed 1-24-67.)
   781.03 DAILY REPORT OF SALES.
   All persons who are licensed to deal in the weapons described in Section
781.01 shall make out and deliver to the Police Department of the City, not
less than forty-eight hours prior to delivery of any such weapon to a purchaser
or donee, a legible and correct report of sale or gift made under authority of
such license on a form to be furnished by the Police Department. The report
shall contain the date of such sale or gift, the name, age and address of the
purchaser or donee, length of time at such address, kind and description of
such weapon, and the purpose given by such person for the purchase of such
weapon. The report shall be signed by the purchaser.
   Satisfactory proof of identity shall be required of the recipient by the
licensee making such sale, gift or exchange of weapon and the means or method
of such identification shall be recorded on the sales record.
(Ord. 1967-2. Passed 1-24-67. )
   781.04 PROHIBITION OF SALE.
   If the Chief of Police or officer designated by him shall find during the
forty-eight hour period commencing with receipt by the Police Department of the
report of sale that the purchaser or donee has violated any ordinance or State
or Federal law pertaining to the use, possession or sale of firearms or
concealable weapons, the sale or gift of such weapon to such person shall be
prohibited and the Chief of Police or officer designated by him shall give
written notice of such prohibition to the licensee and to the purchaser or
donee of such weapon.
(Ord. 1967-2. Passed 1-24-67.)
   781.05 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   In the event that the person licensed to engage in the business of selling
such weapons referred to in Section
781.01 has violated any provision of this chapter, the license of such person
shall be revoked for a period of not less than three years; provided, however,
that such person may appeal to Council for a suspension of the revocation of
his license on the grounds that such revocation is unreasonable and constitutes
an unnecessary hardship. Council may suspend such revocation if it finds that
the public safety or welfare will not be adversely affected. (Ord. 1967-2.
Passed 1-24-67.)
   781.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200. 00) for the
first offense, and not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00), and be imprisoned for a period of not less than
sixty days nor more than six months for any subsequent offense. Every purchase,
sale or gift of any weapon mentioned in this chapter shall be deemed a separate
offense.
(Ord. 1967-2. Passed 1-24-67.)
CHAPTER 791
Detergent Control
791.01   Detergent sales.
791.02   Limitation on sale and distribution.
791.03   Labeling.
791.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Obstruction of watercourses; pollution - see GEN. OFF.
660.04
   Retail dry cleaning establishments - see BUS. REG. Ch.
771
 
   791.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Synthetic detergent" or "detergent" means any cleaning compound
which is available for household use, laundry use, other personal uses or
industrial use, which is composed of organic and inorganic compounds, including
soaps, water softeners, surface active agents, dispersing agents, foaming
agents, buffering agents, builders, fillers, dyes, enzymes and fabric
softeners, whether in the form of crystals, powders, flakes, bars, liquid,
sprays or any other form.
   (b)    "Polyphosphate builder", or "phosphorus" means a water softening and
soil suspending agent made from condensed phosphates, including pyrophosphates,
tripolyphosphates, metaphosphates and glassy phosphates, used as a detergent
ingredient, but does not mean or include a polyphosphate builder or phosphorus
which is essential for medical, scientific or special engineering use under
such conditions and regulations as may be prescribed, after hearing, by
Council.
   (c)    "Recommended use levels" means the amount of synthetic detergent or
detergent which the manufacturer thereof recommends for use per wash load, at
which level the synthetic detergent or detergent will effectively perform its
intended function.
   (d)    "Machine dishwasher" means equipment manufactured for the purpose of
cleaning dishes, glassware and other utensils involved in food preparation,
consumption or use, using a combination of water agitation and high
temperatures.
   (e)    "Dairy equipment", "beverage equipment" and "food processing
equipment", means that equipment used in the production of milk and dairy
products, foods and beverages, including the processing, preparation or
packaging thereof for consumption.
   (f)    "Industrial cleaning equipment" means machinery and other tools used
in cleaning processes during the course of industrial manufacturing, production
and assembly. (Ord. 1971-13. Passed 4-13-71.)
   791.02 LIMITATION ON SALE AND DISTRIBUTION.
   (a)    No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer or expose for sale,
give or furnish any synthetic detergent or detergent containing more than eight
and seven tenths percent of phosphorus by weight, expressed as elemental
phosphorus, within the City as of June 1, 1971. No person, firm or corporation
shall sell, offer or expose for sale, give or furnish any synthetic detergent
or detergent which requires a recommended use level of such synthetic detergent
or detergent which contains more than seven grams of phosphorus by weight,
expressed as elemental phosphorus, within the City as of June 1, 1971.
Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this subsection, synthetic
detergent or detergents manufactured for use in machine dishwashers, dairy
equipment, beverage equipment, food processing equipment and industrial
cleaning equipment shall not be subject to the limitations herein set forth,
but are hereby made expressly subject to the provisions of subsection (b)
hereof.
   (b)    No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer or expose for sale,
give or furnish any synthetic detergent or detergent containing any phosphorus,
expressed as elemental phosphorus, including synthetic detergents or detergents
manufactured for machine dishwashers, dairy equipment, beverage equipment, food
processing equipment and industrial cleaning equipment, within the City as of
July 1, 1973.
   (c)    The concentration of phosphorus by weight, expressed as elemental
phosphorus, in any synthetic detergent or detergent shall be determined by the
current applicable method prescribed by the American Society for Testing and
Materials (A.S.T.M.).
(Ord. 1972-53. Passed 6-13-72.)
   791.03 LABELING.
   No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer or expose for sale, give or
furnish any synthetic detergent or detergent, whether in the form of crystals,
powders, flakes, bars, liquids, sprays or any other form, in the City as of
June 1, 1971, unless the container, wrapper or other packaging thereof is
clearly labeled with respect to its polyphosphate builder or phosphorus
ingredient content, clearly and legibly set forth thereon in terms of
percentage of phosphorus by weight, expressed as elemental phosphorus per
container, wrapper or other packaging thereof, as well as grams of phosphorus,
expressed as elemental phosphorus, per the recommended use level.
(Ord. 1971-13. Passed 4-13-71. )
   791.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or
resists or opposes the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter,
except when otherwise specifically provided, shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the
first offense, and not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense in
any 180 day period, or shall be imprisoned for not more than six months, or
both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which
such person continues or permits any such violation, or failure to comply,
after notification thereof.
(Ord. 1971-13. Passed 4-13-71.)
CHAPTER 793
Abortion Clinics

   adopted.
793.02   File and distribution copies.
793.03   License required; fee; issuance of occupancy permit.

CROSS REFERENCES

   Administering general anesthetic - see GEN. OFF.

   793.01 CUYAHOGA COUNTY BOARD OF HEALTH ABORTION CLINIC REGULATIONS ADOPTED.
   There is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference for the purpose of
establishing rules and regulations for the location and operation of abortion
clinic services, those regulations known as the Board of Health of the Cuyahoga
County General Health District Abortion Clinic Regulations, Section A 1.1
through A 1.15, promulgated and adopted by such Board and filed on October 31,
1973.
(Ord. 1973-92. Passed 1-8-74.)
   793.02 FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
   A complete copy of the Regulations adopted in Section
793.01 is on file with the Clerk of Council for public inspection. A complete
copy is also on file in the County Law Library. In addition, the Clerk of
Council has copies available for distribution to the public, at cost.
(Ord. 1973-92. Passed 1-8-74.)
   793.03 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; ISSUANCE OF OCCUPANCY PERMIT.
   (a)    In addition to the license required by the County Board of Health, no
person shall operate an abortion service clinic within the City without first
having obtained a license therefor issued by the Inspector of Buildings after
such person has complied with all of the provisions of this chapter, including
the provisions of the Regulations adopted in Section
793.01. Such license shall be renewed annually. The annual license fee shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   (b)    The occupancy permit required by Section
1305.07 shall not be issued for the operation of an abortion service clinic
unless and until all required licenses are obtained and the provisions of all
other applicable ordinances and laws, including Part Eleven, the Planning and
Zoning Code, have been complied with.
(Ord. 1973-92. Passed 1-8-74. )
   793.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, including the
provisions of the Regulations adopted in Section
793.01, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months,
or both.
(Ord. 1973-92. Passed 1-8-74.)
CHAPTER 795 
Gas Stations
795.01   Post current gasoline prices.
795.02   Contents and posting requirements.
795.03   Time limitations for posting.
795.04   Total self-service gas stations prohibited.
795.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Sale of gasoline - see Ohio R.C. 3741.14 et seq.
   Advertising - see BUS. REG. Ch.
701
   Automotive service station use district - see P. & Z.
1145.03
   Signs, signboards and billboards - see P. & Z. Ch.
1151
   Storage limits for flammable liquids - see FIRE PREV.
1501.06
   Testing of underground storage tanks - see FIRE PREV.
1501.07
 
   795.01 POSTING CURRENT GASOLINE PRICES.
   No person engaged in the retail sale of gasoline to the general public shall
fail to post on the premises from which such gasoline is sold the current
selling price per gallon of gasoline offered for sale. In the event gasoline is
dispensed or sold at varying prices, the price to be so displayed shall be the
lowest price per grade or type of gasoline that is offered for sale to the
motoring public.
(Ord. 1974-72. Passed 9-10-74. )
   795.02 CONTENTS AND POSTING REQUIREMENTS.
   The posting of prices required in Section
795.01 shall include the posting of the type and grade of the gasoline sold or
offered for sale at retail on the premises. Such posting shall be deemed
accomplished within the meaning of this chapter when the following regulations
are complied with:
   (a)    The posting and display shall consist of an announcement board not
less than six square feet nor more than ten square feet and shall not exceed
eight feet in height. The lettering and numbering on such board shall be not
less than eight inches in height.
   (b)    The announcement board shall be placed within five feet of the front
property line and shall be visible from the street. In the event that a
gasoline service station is located on a corner lot, there must be an
announcement board erected on each area fronting the street, and the prices
shall be visible from such street. In addition, the announcement board shall
include any maximum amount of purchase, if applicable.
   (c)    There shall be no other wording, announcement or graphics other than
the current price per gallon of each grade of gasoline sold.
   (d)    The announcement board required in this section shall be in addition
to the signs permitted by Chapter
1151 .
      (Ord. 1974-72. Passed 9-10-74.)
   795.03 TIME LIMITATIONS FOR POSTING.
   All gasoline service stations presently operating within the City shall
comply with the provisions of this chapter within twenty-one days of its
passage (Ordinance 1974-72, passed September 10, 1974) and all new stations
that open within the City, after the effective date of this chapter, shall
immediately comply with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1974-72. Passed 9-10-74.)
   795.04 TOTAL SELF-SERVICE GAS STATIONS PROHIBITED.
   No gasoline service station shall operate in the City as a totally self-
service gasoline service station. All gasoline service stations shall provide,
at all times during the conduct of their business, at least one island or set
of pumps, dispensing all of the types and grades of gasoline provided by such
gasoline service station, which island or set of pumps shall be serviced by an
employee or attendant, and shall not require the driver or occupant of any
motor vehicle to operate such pumps in order to purchase gasoline.
(Ord. 1977-37. Passed 7-12-77.)
   795.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues. (Ord.
1974-72. Passed 9-10-74. )
CHAPTER 797
Commercial Timbering and Clear-Cutting
EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter, previously a codification of Ordinance 1983-4,
passed January 11, 1983, was re-enacted in its entirety by Ordinances 1983-35,
passed May 8, 1984.
797.01   Definitions.
797.02   Permit required; exemptions.
797.03   Permit application.
797.04   Permit review.
797.05   Granting of permit.
797.06   Release of bond.
797.99   Penalty; equitable remedies.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Timber and lumber - see Ohio R.C. 981.01 et seq.
   Injuring trees - see GEN. OFF.
642.06
   Removal of weeds - see GEN. OFF.
642.28
   Removal of trees, weeds and grasses by Municipality - see S. & P. S.
909.02 ,
909.03
   Planting of trees in public places - see S. & P. S.
909.04
 
   797.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Commercial timbering operation" means the cutting of trees, bearing
a trunk diameter of not less than twelve inches, as measured at one-half the
distance between the ground and the first branch, for the purpose or with the
intent of offering such trees for sale, or selling or exchanging such trees for
consideration or anything of value.
   (b)    "Clear-cutting" means the removal of trees and other vegetation from
a site in preparation for the development of such site.
      (Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
   797.02 PERMIT REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS.
   No property owner, lessee, agent, employee, corporation or other person
shall clear-cut or engage in any commercial timbering operation within the City
without first obtaining a permit therefor from the Inspector of Buildings.
However, no such permit shall be required for clear-cutting for any development
for which site plans, plats or improvement drawings have been approved by the
Planning Commission and/or Council. In addition, no such permit shall be
required for the removal of ten or fewer trees within any consecutive twelve-
month period in either of the following cases:
   (a)    From a residential lot containing an existing residential structure;
or
   (b)    For construction of a new residential structure on a single
residential lot for which a building permit has been issued, even if such trees
are sold or offered for sale or other consideration.
      (Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
   797.03 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Any person requesting a permit, as required by this chapter, shall make an
application to the Inspector of Buildings in writing, listing or accompanied
by:
   (a)    The name and address of each owner of the premises upon which the
commercial timbering operation or clear-cutting will occur;
   (b)    The name and address of the party who or which will undertake the
commercial timbering operation or clear-cutting;
   (c)    A detailed plan or sketch of the area to be commercially timbered or
clear-cut;
   (d)    A legal description of the property;
   (e)    A before and after topographical survey map of the property;
   (f)    A detailed plan outlining erosion control measures, sedimentation
control, cleanup procedures and after-care and providing for an appropriate
buffer area of natural screening; and
   (g)    A cash or surety bond, in such form as approved by the Law Director,
in favor of the City, in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000), signed
by the owner of the premises upon which the commercial timbering operation or
clear-cutting is to be conducted and each of the persons or other legal
entities with whom arrangements have been made for such commercial timbering or
clear-cutting.
   The application fee for such permit shall be two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and shall be paid to the Inspector of Buildings with the application.
Where more than ten trees are being cut from a residential lot containing an
existing residential structure, the application fee shall be fifty dollars
($50.00).
(Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
   797.04 PERMIT REVIEW.
   In addition to his or her own review, the Inspector of Buildings shall
submit the application for a permit and all accompanying documents to the City
Engineer for his or her review and request a report and recommendations from
him or her regarding the potential risks and necessary protections against soil
erosion, stream siltation and the necessary after-care measures to be
undertaken. Such recommendations from the City Engineer shall be attached as
conditions to the issuance of the permit, if granted.
(Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
   797.05 GRANTING OF PERMIT .
   A permit shall be granted if the Inspector of Buildings finds, in regard to
such proposed commercial timbering operation or clear-cutting, that:
   (a)    The requested operation and/or any earth removal or change of grade
associated with such operation will not result in undue erosion or undue stream
siltation and contiguous or adjacent properties will not be adversely affected.
   (b)    Adequate assurances have been provided by the applicant that all of
the cordwood, branches, brush, rubble and refuse resulting from the requested
operation will be removed from the premises or cut up, chipped or mulched and
placed on the forest floor in such a way that no fire hazard will result
therefrom.
   (c)    The requested operation will comply with all Federal and State laws
and these Codified Ordinances, including, but not limited to, the requirements
of Chapters
1351  and
1352  of Part Thirteen - the Building Code.
   (d)    The bond required by Section
797.03 has been posted.
   (e)    The requested operation will not tend to create a nuisance.
   If a permit is granted, the Inspector of Buildings shall specify the hours
during which the requested operation may be conducted, designate the streets,
if any, which may be used for the hauling of timber and provide for such other
controls, such as the prevention of mud on streets, as are necessary to ensure
a clean and safe timbering operation. He or she shall see that all of the
provisions of these Codified Ordinances regarding use of City streets are
complied with, and he or she will inspect the operation to ensure compliance
with the permit and all conditions attached to it.
   In granting such permit, the Inspector of Buildings shall also include as
conditions any recommendations of the City Engineer pursuant to Section
797.04 and/or such other reasonable conditions as may be necessary to satisfy
the criteria of this chapter and to protect the public peace, health, safety
and welfare.
(Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
   797.06 RELEASE OF BOND.
   The bond specified in Section
797.03 shall not be returned or released until such time as all provisions of
this chapter and all conditions of the permit have been satisfactorily complied
with, as determined by the Inspector of Buildings, including, but not limited
to, clean-up operations and flood, sediment and erosion control measures.
(Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
   797.99 PENALTY; EQUITABLE REMEDIES.
   (a)    Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or any subsequent offense, such person
is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not more
than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty
days, or both. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse
the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be required
to correct or remedy such violations within a reasonable time. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation
continues.
   (b)    In addition to the penalty provided in subsection (a) hereof, the
Inspector of Buildings may revoke any permit issued by him or her pursuant to
Section
797.05 and may also, at his or her discretion, institute and maintain, in the
name of the Municipality, an appropriate action at law or in equity to restrain
any violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 1983-35. Passed 5-8-84.)
 
CHAPTER 798
Food Trucks
798.01   Definitions.
798.02   Food truck permit.
798.03   License and permit requirements for operation.
798.04   General requirements.
798.05   Operation in right of way; public property.
798.06   Products for sale.
798.07   Restrictions on hours of operation.
798.99   Penalty.
798.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Food” shall mean a raw, cooked or processed edible substance, ice,
beverage or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or part
for human consumption.
   (b)   “Food truck” means a vehicle or vehicle and trailer propelled by an
engine which has been specifically designed or used for mobile food vending.
   (c)   “Food truck permit” shall mean the permit issued by the City Safety
Director, or his designee, pursuant to this chapter.
   (d)   “Mobile Food Service License” and “Mobile Food Establishment License”
means the official document issued by the Cuyahoga County Board of Health or
other health department in the State of Ohio possessing the appropriate
licensing authority which allows the operation of a food truck in Cuyahoga
County.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.02  FOOD TRUCK PERMIT.
   Food truck operators shall apply annually for and receive a Food Truck
Permit through the City Police Department prior to any operation within the
City.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.03    LICENSE AND PERMIT REQUIREMENTS FOR OPERATION.
   (a)   No person shall offer for sale any food from any food truck within the
City without a current and valid Mobile Food Service or Mobile Food
Establishment License issued by the Cuyahoga County Board of Health or other
health department in the State of Ohio possessing the appropriate licensing
authority.
   (b)   A Mobile Food Service or Mobile Food Establishment License must be
clearly and conspicuously displayed on the food truck during all times of
operation for inspection by the Cuyahoga County Board of Health.
   (c)   A Food Truck Permit must be obtained by the operator of any food truck
before the food truck may operate within the City.
   (d)   All food trucks shall be subject to inspection during operation by the
Division of Fire for compliance with local and state fire code laws and
regulations.
   (e)   All food trucks shall comply with inspection requirements, including
the possibility of random inspections, as set forth in the permit packet issued
by the City.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.04  GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   All food trucks operating in the City of Independence must keep the
surrounding area immediately adjacent to the food truck clean and must dispose
all waste generated from the operation.
   (b)   All food trucks must be constructed to internally store and contain
all sewage and waste water for proper disposal and to prevent ground water
contamination.  There shall be no discharge of any sewage and waste water onto
the ground or into any storm water or sanitary sewers within the City.
   (c)   No food truck shall utilize loud speakers or other noise-making
devices in such a way to create a nuisance, or in violation of the City’s
ordinances.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.05  OPERATION IN RIGHT OF WAY; PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   (a)   Food truck operators are prohibited from parking or operating in the
public right of way or upon any City street unless in conjunction with a
community event or a parade/assemblage as permitted in Section
 311.05 of the Codified Ordinances.
   (b)   Food truck operators are prohibited from parking or operating on
public property, including public parks, without prior written authorization
from the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.06  PRODUCTS FOR SALE.
   Food trucks shall only offer for sale food.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.07  RESTRICTIONS ON HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (a)   Food trucks may not operate between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:30
a.m., except through the issuance of an extended hours permit as provided by
subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   The hours of operation may be expanded upon the issuance of an
extended hours permit from the City’s Safety Director, or his designee, in
advance of any event in which the hours of operation violate those set forth in
subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
798.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a fourth degree
misdemeanor.  (Ord. 2017-43.  Passed 3-14-17.)
 
CHAPTER 799
Food and Beverage Sales
799.01    Unlawful exposure by employees.
799.02   Assisting unlawful exposure prohibited.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Sex related offenses - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
666
   Adult entertainment businesses - see P. & Z.
1142.01
 
   799.01 UNLAWFUL EXPOSURE BY EMPLOYEES.
   (a)    No person shall, while acting as a server, waiter, waitress,
entertainer or employee, in an establishment which serves either food alone,
beverages alone, or food and beverages (the term "beverages" as used herein
shall include, but shall not be limited to, alcoholic beverages) for
consumption on the premises of the establishment:
      (1)    Expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anal
region, or pubic hair region; or
      (2)    Expose any device, costume or covering which gives the appearance
of or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anal region or
pubic hair region; or
      (3)    Expose any portion of the female breast at or below the areola
thereof.
   (b)    A person shall be deemed to be a server, waiter, waitress,
entertainer or employee if such person acts in that capacity without regard to
whether or not such person is paid any compensation by the owner or management
of the establishment in which the activity is performed.
   (c)    Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree. (Ord. 1992-50. Passed 1-12-93.)
   799.02 ASSISTING UNLAWFUL EXPOSURE PROHIBITED.
   (a)    No person shall cause, permit, procure, counsel or assist any person
to expose or simulate exposure as prohibited in Section
799.01.
   (b)    Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree. (Ord. 1992-50. Passed 1-12-93.)

CHAPTER 901
Street Excavations
901.01   Permit required; deposit.
901.02   Rules for excavations and tunneling.
901.03   Completion by Municipality; refund.
901.04   Barricades; lights; insurance.
901.05   Protection of public safety and convenience.
901.06   Obstruction of driveways.
901.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Establishment and care of streets - see Ohio R.C. 715.19, 717.01, 723.01
   Openings by the Municipality - see Ohio R.C. 723.02
   Damage from excavation near street - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
   Permit for street excavation - see TRAF.
311.01(d)
   Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
660.16
   Inspection of work - see S. & P. S. Ch.
907
   Construction or extension of utilities - see S. & P. S. Ch.
921
   Subdivision design standards - see P. & Z. Ch.
1111 et seq.
 
   901.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; DEPOSIT.
   Before opening, excavating or tunneling under any public street or road in
the Municipality, or within five feet of the pavement in such public street or
road, the person desiring to do so shall obtain a permit therefor from the
Service Director and shall deposit with the Service Director an amount of money
estimated to cover the cost of backfilling and repairing the pavement, berm,
tree lawn or tunnel and to cover the cost of the Municipality for supervision,
inspection and police protection.
   No such permit shall be issued for opening or excavating such street or road
if the Service Director shall determine that such opening or excavation is
unnecessary, would create a traffic or safety hazard or if the installation or
connection desired to be made can be safely made by tunneling or augering under
such public street or road.
(Ord. 1958-31. Passed 7-22-58.)
   901.02 RULES FOR EXCAVATIONS AND TUNNELING.
   All cuts, openings, excavations or tunneling in any public street or road
shall be subject to the inspection, supervision and approval of the Service
Director who may require approval of the Municipal Engineer and who may hire
inspectors for such work at the cost of the permittee. All material taken from
the excavation or tunnel shall be removed and in no case used for backfilling.
The excavation shall be backfilled with sand and well puddled and compacted.
The Service Director may require a cut in the pavement to be paved temporarily
or otherwise covered if the fill requires settling and the same to be
maintained at the permittee's expense. When the Service Director has determined
that the trench has fully settled, the temporary filling shall be removed and
permanent repairs made.
   The opening for tunnels shall be no closer than five feet to the paved or
traveled portion of the road unless the Service Director permits a closer
opening which will require a permit for both an opening or excavation and
tunneling. Tunnels shall be filled with sand so that no open spaces or pockets
remain, and the openings for such tunnel shall be filled and closed.
(Ord. 1958-31. Passed 7-22-58.)
   901.03 COMPLETION BY MUNICIPALITY; REFUND.
   If the temporary or permanent pavement is not made as required by the
Service Director, or if any of the work is not satisfactorily completed, the
same may be performed by the Municipality and paid for from the deposit
provided for in this chapter. If such deposit is insufficient to cover all of
the costs of the Municipality, the balance shall be collected from the
permittee. Whatever portion of such deposit is not used by the Municipality for
such purpose or for the expense of the Municipality for supervision, inspection
and police protection shall be refunded to the permittee.
(Ord. 1958-31. Passed 7-22-58.)
   901.04 BARRICADES; LIGHTS; INSURANCE.
   Whatever guards, warning devices and lights around such work as may be
required by the Chief of Police or Service Director shall be maintained by the
applicant, and the applicant shall be required to satisfy the Service Director
that he carries insurance covering Municipal liability in satisfactory amounts
and forms.
(Ord. 1820. Passed 5-22-56.)
   901.05 PROTECTION OF THE PUBLIC SAFETY AND CONVENIENCE.
   The convenience and safety of the public and the prompt and satisfactory
restoration of the pavement shall be paramount considerations in the granting
of any permit under the provisions of this chapter. The Chief of Police or
Service Director may issue such further regulations, requirements or conditions
in connection with any opening or excavation in a public street as either of
such officials deems necessary for the protection and preservation of the
public peace, safety, welfare and convenience.
(Ord. 1958-25. Passed 5-27-58.)
   901.06 OBSTRUCTION OF DRIVEWAY.
   No contractor or other person doing work in any of the streets of the
Municipality shall close or in any manner disturb the property in the streets
of the Municipality in front of any driveway or in any manner excavate or
disturb any street in such a manner as to make inaccessible the right of
ingress and egress over and upon the driveway to and from such adjoining
property for more than eight hours without obtaining written permission from
the Inspector of Buildings. (Ord. 668. Passed 12-26-28.)
   901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day's continued violation shall constitute
a separate offense.
CHAPTER 903
Driveway Culverts; Roadside Ditches
903.01   Permit required; regulations.
903.02   Permit for changes.
903.03   Fee for culvert installation.
903.04   Fee for changes.
903.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Drainage and watercourses - see GEN. OFF.
660.13 et seq.
   Grade for new construction - see BLDG.
1305.06
   Damage to driveways - see BLDG. Ch.
1349
 
   903.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; REGULATIONS.
   Before installing any driveway culvert along a roadside ditch within the
dedicated portion of any public street within the Municipality, the owner of
the abutting property shall first obtain written permission from the Service
Director to make such installation. The length, diameter and type of material
of such culvert, the depth and level of such culvert shall first be approved by
the Municipal Engineer, and the installation of such culvert shall be subject
to the approval and inspection of the Service Director.
   Every culvert pipe hereinafter installed in a public street in the
Municipality shall be at least sixteen feet in length, at least twelve inches
in diameter and the flow line of such culvert pipe shall be at least one foot,
four inches in depth below the edge of the pavement of the street. (Ord. 1957-
35. Passed 12-10-57.)
   903.02 PERMIT FOR CHANGES.
   No person shall fill in, cover, regrade or alter the course or grade of any
roadside ditch or otherwise change the grade of a ditch, tree lawn or any
portion of a dedicated street within the Municipality without first having
obtained permission from the Service Director, and any such filling in,
covering, grading or alteration shall be subject to the approval and inspection
at all times of the Municipal Engineer.
(Ord. 1957-35. Passed 12-10-57.)
   903.03 FEE FOR CULVERT INSTALLATION.
   Every person making an installation of a driveway culvert pipe shall pay to
the Municipality a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to defray the expense of
inspection and approval. (Ord. 1960-40. Passed 11-10-60.)
   903.04 FEE FOR CHANGES.
   Every person otherwise filling in, covering, regrading or altering the
course or grading of a roadside drainage ditch or in any manner changing the
grade of a ditch, tree lawn, or other portion of a dedicated street shall first
pay to the Municipality a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to defray the cost of
approval and inspection.
(Ord. 1957-35. Passed 12-10-57.)
   903.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day's continued offense shall be
considered a separate
violation. (Ord. 1957-35. Passed 12-10-57.)
CHAPTER 905
Sidewalks
905.01   Cleaning and repairing sidewalks.
905.02    Policy to install sidewalks on both sides of a City street or
   roadway for major road improvement projects.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Sidewalks and gutters - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
   Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
   Driving and parking on sidewalks, street lawns or curbs - see TRAF.
331.22
   Sidewalks to be cleaned of ice and snow - see GEN. OFF.

   905.01 CLEANING AND REPAIRING SIDEWALKS.
   No owner of any lot or land abutting upon any street shall refuse, fail or
neglect to repair or keep in repair and free from nuisance and obstruction the
sidewalk in front of such lot or land after due notice of a resolution of
Council ordering the repair of such sidewalk, the removal of such obstruction
or the abatement of such nuisance.
   If the owner or person having charge of such land fails to comply with such
notice, Council shall cause the sidewalks to be repaired. All expenses and
labor costs incurred shall, when approved by Council, be paid out of the
municipal funds not otherwise appropriated. Council shall make a written return
to the County Auditor of its action, with a statement of the charges for its
services, the amount paid for labor, the fees of the officers serving such
notices, and a proper description of the premises. Such amounts, when allowed,
shall be entered upon the tax duplicate and be a lien upon such lands from and
after the date of the entry and be collected as other taxes and returned to the
Municipality with the General Fund.
(Ord. 1958-25. Passed 5-27-58. )
   905.02 POLICY TO INSTALL SIDEWALKS ON BOTH SIDES OF A CITY STREET OR ROADWAY
FOR MAJOR ROAD IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS.
   Council orders as a general policy, and when not otherwise addressed in the
City’s Codified Ordinances regarding subdivisions, that sidewalks on both sides
of any City street or roadway shall be installed during major road improvement
projects unless it is determined by the City Engineer that installation of one
or both of said sidewalks would not be practicable or feasible.  (Ord. 2000-
33.  Passed 5-9-00.)

   907.01 INSPECTION; FEE.
   All permits for the laying or constructing of pavements, sewers, water
lines, gas lines, sidewalks, electric conduits, ditches, gutters, sign posts
and any wire or guy posts or telephone posts, shall be conditioned upon an
inspection, during the process of completion of any such laying or opening of
the aforesaid, by an inspector appointed by the Mayor, and the City shall be
reimbursed for such inspection charge and for other expenses incurred at the
rate of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per hour for every hour of inspection by the
person to whom such permit is conditionally issued.
(Ord. 1991-59. Passed 11-12-91.)
   907.02 BOND.

Service Director in such amount as he may deem advisable, not exceeding one
thousand dollars ($1,000), conditioned upon the payment of the services of the
inspector in accordance with the provisions of Section
907.01.
(Ord. 1333. Passed 7-9-46.)
CHAPTER 909
Trees, Weeds and Grass
909.01   Trimming of trees, shrubbery.
909.02   Removal of trees, weeds, grasses by Municipality.
909.03   Assessment of costs by Municipality.
909.04   Planting of trees in public  places.
909.05   Grass lawns required.
909.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
   Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
   Injury or destruction of trees growing products - see GEN. OFF.
642.06,
642.28
 
   909.01 TRIMMING OF TREES, SHRUBBERY.
   The owner of every lot or parcel of land within the corporate limits upon
which a tree, plant or shrubbery stands with any part thereof upon or
overhanging a public street or sidewalk shall conform to the regulations herein
provided; otherwise, the Municipality shall cause such trees to be trimmed or
cut down and removed in accordance with such regulations and assess the cost
thereof against the owner of such lot or parcel of land:
   (a)   Such owner shall trim or cause to be trimmed such tree, plant or
shrubbery so that a clear height of eight feet between the lowest branches of
the same and the street or sidewalk is maintained;
   (b)   Such owner shall trim or remove, as the case may require, every dead,
decayed or broken tree, plant or shrubbery, or part thereof, so that the same
shall not fall to the street or sidewalk;
   (c)   Such owner shall cut down and remove any tree, plant or shrubbery, or
any part thereof, as may be necessary to provide a clear and unobstructed view
of traffic from all directions at any street intersection, or to abate any
nuisance necessary to protect life, limb or property of persons, drivers of any
vehicles or pedestrians using such street or sidewalk. (Ord. 1958-25. Passed 5-
27-58.)
   909.02 REMOVAL OF TREES, WEEDS, GRASSES BY MUNICIPALITY.
   In the event the owner does not trim or remove any tree, plant or shrubbery,
or any part thereof, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, then
the Council Clerk is hereby authorized and it is hereby declared to be his duty
to have enforced the provisions of this chapter, and to cause to be trimmed or
removed such tree, plant or shrubbery, or part thereof, and cut and remove all
grass and weeds. (Ord. 1958-25. Passed 5-27-58.)
   909.03 ASSESSMENT OF COSTS BY MUNICIPALITY.
   Whenever any tree, plant or shrubbery, or part thereof, or weeds and grass
are growing in any street, public place or upon private property contiguous to
a street, sidewalk or public place, and is trimmed or removed by the
Municipality then, after the work is done, the Municipality shall give five
days’ notice, by regular mail, to the owner of such lot or parcel of land, at
his last known address, to pay the cost of such trimming or removal of trees,
plants, shrubbery, grass or weeds, or parts thereof, which notice shall be
accompanied by a statement of the amount of cost incurred, and in the event the
same is not paid within thirty days after the mailing of such notice, then such
amount shall be certified to the County Auditor for collection the same as
other taxes and assessments are collected. (Ord. 1958-25. Passed 5-27-58.)
   909.04 PLANTING OF TREES IN PUBLIC PLACES.
   No tree, ornamental plant or shrub shall be planted on any public street or
ground within the Municipality except by persons employed by the Municipality
for that purpose, or with and in conformance to the written permission of the
Service Director, who shall grant such permission only if he finds that the
proposed planting will not interfere with the appropriate public use of the
street or ground and is consistent with any plan of planting in effect or
proposed thereon. Such permission shall specify the manner in which the
planting shall be done and the type of tree, plant or shrub proposed to be
planted in order to insure proper consistency and lack of interference and to
promote the proper growth of the tree, plant or shrub proposed to be planted.
(Ord. 1960-15. Passed 3-22-60.)
   909.05 GRASS LAWNS REQUIRED.
   Every owner of a lot or parcel of land with an inhabitable structure thereon
shall plant grass seed or otherwise provide for a full and complete grass
covering of all lawn areas of such property. For new structures, provision for
a grass lawn shall be made within one year of the receipt of an occupancy
permit from the City. (Ord. 1972-101. Passed 1-23-73.)
   909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than fifty dollars
($50.00). Each day's violation or each repeated violation by the same person
shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1958-25. Passed 5-27-58.)
CHAPTER 910
Tree Commission
910.01   Creation and establishment of a Tree Commission.
910.02   Duties and responsibilities.
910.03   Term of office.
910.04   Compensation.
910.05   Operation.
910.06   Reporting.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
   Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
   Generally - see S. & P.S. Ch.
909
 
   910.01 CREATION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A TREE COMMISSION.
   There is hereby created and established a Tree Commission for the City,
which shall consist of six regular members, comprised of the City Planner as an
ad hoc, non-voting member, a member of Council, and four citizens and residents
of this City, two appointed by the Mayor and two appointed by Council. The
Mayor or his representative shall also be a member. In addition, the Commission
shall have the right to request Council or the Mayor, with respect to
capacities and limitations, to call in consultants as it sees fit.
(Ord. 1993-19. Passed 6-8-93.)
   910.02 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)    General Powers. The Tree Commission shall have the power to study,
investigate, plan, advise, report and recommend to Council and the Mayor any
action, program, plan or legislative act which the Commission shall find or
determine to be necessary or advisable for the care, preservation, trimming,
planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees or shrubs within the
City.
   (b)    City Tree Plan. It shall be the responsibility of the Commission to
study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer
a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting,
removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other
public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to Council, and upon its
acceptance and approval, shall constitute the official comprehensive City of
Independence Tree Plan.
(Ord. 1993-19. Passed 6-8-93.)
   910.03 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The term of two of the members appointed to the first Commission shall be
for two years and the term of two members of the first Commission shall be for
four years. Successors to those members appointed shall thereafter be appointed
to similar terms as those exiting the Commission. The term of the Council
representative shall be two years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur
during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the
unexpired portion of the term.
(Ord. 1993-19. Passed 6-8-93.)
   910.04 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 1993-19. Passed 6-8-93.)
   910.05 OPERATION.
   The Commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and
regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings, to be administered by the
Clerk of Council. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the
transaction of business.
(Ord. 1993-19. Passed 6-8-93.)
   910.06 REPORTING.
   The Commission shall report to the Mayor and Council on at least a quarterly
basis. (Ord. 1993-19. Passed 6-8-93.)

   921.01 PERMIT FOR CONSTRUCTION OR EXTENSION.
   No person shall repair, relocate, extend or construct telephone, telegraph,
electric transmission, gas or water lines or equipment in connection therewith
under, across or over public property within the limits of the Municipality
without first obtaining a permit therefor from the Service Director. All
requests for permits to construct new telephone, telegraph, electric
transmission, gas or water lines in new corridors, whether affecting private or
public property within the City, shall also be approved by Council. The term
"public property," as used in this chapter, means any and all areas of the City
owned by or under the control of the City, including streets, highways,
sidewalks, tree lawn areas, public parking lots and public parks and
playgrounds.
(Ord. 1977-4. Passed 2-8-77.)
   921.02 PERMIT FEE; BOND.
   Upon granting the permit required by Section
921.01, the Service Director may fix a fee therefor, or require a cash or
surety bond, for private individuals or companies to insure satisfactory
restoration of public property. "Satisfactory restoration," as used herein and
which must be performed by all applicants, whether public utilities or private,
shall include the use of grass sod for any restoration work on areas of public
property where a grass lawn exists.
(Ord. 1977-4. Passed 2-8-77.)
   921.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day that such violation is permitted to
exist shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 828. Passed 12-13-32.)
