   Architectural Board of Review - see BLDG. Ch.
1309
 
   1303.01 PERMIT APPLICATION; PROFESSIONAL FEES.
   Before proceeding with the construction, enlargement, alteration, repair,
remodeling or moving of any building or other structure, a permit shall first
be obtained from the Building Commissioner by the owner of the premises or by a
person acting as his or her agent under written authority of such owner, and
such written authority shall accompany any application for a permit by such
agent. Such application shall be made in writing and upon printed forms
prescribed and furnished by the Building Commissioner. It shall, except for
removals, be accompanied by three complete sets of plans conforming to the
requirements of Sections
1303.02 and
1303.03. Upon the filing of such application and plans, the applicant shall pay
a permit fee as provided for by ordinance of Council. In addition to such
permit fee and only in the case of buildings other than single-family
residences, the applicant shall also be required to pay the sum of thirty
dollars ($30.00) for the processing costs of engineering and architectural
review and inspection by City personnel. For commercial or complex plans, the
applicant shall also be required to immediately reimburse the City for the
actual cost incurred by the City from any engineer, plans reviewer,  or
construction professional for such extraordinary time spent for such
architectural review. 
(Ord. 2013-30.  Passed 11-12-13.)
   1303.02 PLANS AND DRAWINGS; SCALE.
   All plans and drawings required to be filed with the Building Commissioner
in connection with the application for a building permit must be prepared in
compliance with all of the requirements of the Building Code, the Ohio Building
Code and the Residential Code of Ohio.  (Ord. 2013-30.  Passed 11-12-13.)
   1303.03 REQUIREMENT OF DRAWINGS.
   All plans and specifications submitted in connection with the application
for building permit:
   (a)    Shall include a plot plan showing the relation of buildings to lot
line, contour lines, showing building and drainage elevations.
   (b)    Shall include basement or foundation plan, floor plans, front, rear
and side elevation and typical wall section;
   (c)    Shall include sufficient scale details to define the character of the
exterior design and a typical wall section through the front face of the
building showing front height, window height, construction, foundation and
material to be used;
   (d)    Shall include location of buildings on adjacent lots;
   (e)    Shall include a schedule of exterior materials, finishes and colors.
   (f)   Shall include all information as required by Section 106 of the Ohio
Residential Code.
   Site and location plans shall show existing adjacent finished grades and
proposed finished grades relative to the street grades.
   In addition, for all commercial buildings, three sets of landscaping plans
shall be submitted, one to the Planning Commission, one to the Architectural
Board of Review and one to the Building Commissioner. Such landscaping plans
shall, at a minimum, provide for the replacement of every tree by a like number
of seedlings, for every tree to be damaged or destroyed.
   Plans for remodeling buildings which affect the exterior appearance shall be
accompanied by a drawing sufficient to show the existing building and
surroundings.
   The Building Commissioner may, by regulations issued by him and approved by
the Architectural Board of Review, require such other reasonable plans,
specifications and details thereof as may be necessary to properly evaluate
safety, architectural and use features of all buildings proposed to be built or
altered.
(Ord. 2007-07.  Passed 3-13-07.)
   1303.04 APPROVAL OF PLANS; LAPSE OF APPROVAL.
   All applications for building permits, together with plans and
specifications for the construction, reconstruction or alteration of any
building, shall be submitted to the Architectural Board of Review as provided
in Chapter
1309, to the City Engineer for the establishment of a grade in accordance with
Section
1305.06, and to the Service Director, Fire Chief and Police Chief, for review
of the same as to compliance with applicable provisions of these Codified
Ordinances.
   An application for a building permit, together with plans and specifications
for the addition to or alteration of any commercial or industrial building,
shall be submitted to the Planning Commission, in addition to such Board and
officials, for review of the same as to compliance with the zoning and parking
ordinances of the City.
   When the Building Commissioner is satisfied that such plans and
specifications have been approved for compliance by the Board, the Commission,
when applicable, and such other officials, and when the Commissioner is
satisfied that such plans and specifications conform in all respects to the
provisions and requirements of this Building Code and all other applicable
ordinances of the Municipality and the laws of the State, he shall stamp his
approval upon such plans and specifications. One copy of such plans shall be
returned to the owner, architect or builder and shall be kept at the building
site until the same is completed and a final inspection of such building is
made by the Commissioner. The second copy of such plans shall remain with the
Commissioner and, upon completion, shall be placed on file with the
Municipality.
   Failure of the owner or his agent to obtain all necessary approvals by the
Board, the Commission and other officials, where applicable, and to obtain the
permit required by Section
1303.01 within six months of the date such plans and specifications are
approved by the Commission or the date the owner made initial application for
such permit, whichever is earlier, shall cause any approval by the Board, the
Commission or others to lapse. The Commission may, for good cause shown, extend
such time for obtaining a permit for not more than one year.
   If approval of plans and specifications lapses under this section, the owner
or his or her agent shall again comply with all the provisions of this chapter,
including the payment of permit fees, before proceeding with the construction,
enlargement, alteration, repair, remodeling or moving of any building or other
structure.
(Ord. 1981-9. Passed 3-10-81.)
   1303.05 REJECTION OF PLANS.
   If the plans or specifications referred to in Section
1303.04 are not approved by the Architectural Board of Review, the Planning
Commission, when applicable, or the Building Commissioner, one set of such
plans shall be returned to the applicant and one set shall be retained on file
with the Municipality.
(Ord. 1973-78. Passed 11-27-73. )
   1303.06 CHANGING OF PLANS.
   It shall be unlawful to erase, alter or modify any lines, figures or color
contained upon any such drawings or specifications filed with the Building
Commissioner. If during the progress of the execution of such work, it is
desired to deviate in any manner affecting the construction of any essential of
the building from the terms of the application, plans and specifications,
notice of such intention to alter or deviate shall be given in writing to the
Commissioner, and the approval of the Architectural Board of Review and of the
Commissioner shall first be obtained in writing before such alteration or
deviation may be made, or the Commissioner may require that new plans shall be
submitted and approved therefor. (Ord. 1835. Passed 7-31-56. )
   1303.07 LOOK-ALIKE HOMES.
   (a)    The Building Commissioner shall not approve any application for a
permit to erect, construct, alter or enlarge any detached one-family dwelling
in any residential area of the City which shall be like or substantially like
any neighboring dwelling then in existence or for which a building permit has
been issued, or which is included in the same building permit application, in
more than three of the following seven respects:
      (1)    Height of the main roof ridge or the highest point of the roof
beams above the elevation of the first floor;
      (2)    Height of the main roof ridge above the top of the plate;
      (3)    Length of the main roof ridge;
      (4)    Width between outside walls at the ends of the dwelling measured
under the main roof at right angles to the length thereof;
      (5)    Relative location of windows in the front elevation and in each of
both side elevations with respect to each other and with respect to any door,
chimney, porch or attached garage in the same elevation;
      (6)    Relative location of any attached garage, porch or gable, if any,
in the front elevation with respect to each other and the remainder of the
dwelling;
      (7)    Building materials and color to be used in the exterior surface of
the dwelling.
   (b)    Dwellings shall be deemed to be like each other in any dimension with
respect to which the difference between them is not more than two feet.
Dwellings between which the only difference in relative location of elements is
end to end or side to side reversal of such elements shall be deemed to be like
each other in relative location of such elements.
   (c)    A permit to erect, construct, alter or enlarge any dwelling in a
residence district shall not be issued by the Building Commissioner if the
Architectural Board of Review determines that the architectural design of said
dwelling is similar to any other dwelling within three lots adjacent to the
subject dwelling or one directly across the street and the dwellings on either
side of it.
   (d)    All plans for a new or remodeled residential structure as required by
the Building Commissioner prior to the issuance of a building permit shall also
include the following information:
      (1)    A copy of the subdivision plat indicating the sublot upon which a
building permit is being applied for and adjacent sublots on the same side and
across the street from the subject sublot; and
      (2)    Photographs of existing dwellings within three adjacent lots and
directly across the street and the dwellings on either side of it from the lot
upon which an application for a building permit is being filed.
         (Ord. 1987-36. Passed 2-9-88.)
   1303.08 ELECTRICAL WIRING FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION.
   All plans presented to the City after October 1, 1992, for new commercial
and industrial construction shall provide for all underground wiring between
such new construction and the utility right of way. As used in this section,
wiring includes electrical, telephone, cable television or any wiring providing
public utility service to such new construction.
(Ord. 1992-31. Passed 9-8-92.)

   1305.01 PERMIT TO ERECT PART OF BUILDING.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the Building
Commissioner from issuing a permit for the erection of any part of the building
or structure where plans and detailed statements have been presented for the
same before the entire plans and detailed statements of such building or
structure have been submitted; provided that a complete set of all such plans
and specifications as hereinbefore prescribed shall be placed on file before
the foundation wall is brought to grade or to a height to receive the first
tier of beams, girders or joists.  In event of any owner permitting his agent
to put in foundations or work provided in this section which may not be in
keeping with the final plans and which may be contrary to the requirements of
this Code, the Building Commissioner will not be bound by the work already done
from the incomplete drawings, and the owner proceeds with such work as is
authorized by this section entirely at his own risk.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.02 PERMITS FOR SUPERSTRUCTURES.
   No permit shall be issued for the erection of the superstructure of any
building above the foundation or basement wall until all of the approved plans
and specifications and details required by this Building Code are placed on
file with the Building Commissioner.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.03 EXPIRATION FOR FAILURE TO COMMENCE WORK.
   All building permits issued under the authority of this City shall
automatically expire and be null and void six months after the date of the
issuance thereof, unless the work for which the permit was issued is commenced
prior to the expiration of such six months’ period.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.04 EXPIRATION FOR WORK CESSATION; SAFETY PRECAUTIONS.
   In the event such work is commenced and there is an interruption or
cessation of such work for a period of six months or more on any project for
which a building permit has been issued, then upon notice by the Building
Commissioner to the holder of the building permit, which notice may be posted
on the premises wherein the permitted work is being carried on, the building
permit shall become null and void and no further work shall be performed unless
a new permit is taken out by the owner or his agent and the fees provided for
an original permit in Chapter
1307 are paid therefor.  Whenever there is a cessation of work for any period,
the holder of the permit shall fill in or protect all excavations and take such
measures to protect property and materials on the site and abate any nuisance
or dangerous condition as the Building Commissioner shall direct.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.05 WORK COMPLETION REQUIRED WITHIN ONE YEAR.
   Within one year after the date of original issue of any building permit, all
work to be performed under such permit, including finished grading, leveling of
all excavations, provision for surfaced driveways or motor vehicle access to
any main building and adequate enclosure of and preservation from the elements
of the building, all structures for which the permit is issued must be
completed in accordance with the plans and specifications.  Such enclosure and
preservation must be sufficient to permit the use of any building for which it
is designed and sufficient to prevent the creation of nuisance or dangerous
conditions and unnecessary deterioration of materials, and shall be
sufficiently complete so as to present an appearance which will not have an
adverse effect upon the surrounding area or the values of the surrounding
property.  Such one year period shall run regardless of the issuance of a stop-
work order issued by the Building Commissioner for failure to comply with, or
for a violation of, any provisions of this Building Code.
(Ord.  2006-29.  Passed 7-11-06.)
   1305.06 SITE IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED WITHIN 18 MONTHS.
   Completion of any structure as required by Section
1305.05  shall include site improvements.  The site shall be planted with grass
and suitably landscaped within eighteen months from the date of the issuance of
the permit.
(Ord. 2006-31.  Passed 7-11-06.)
   1305.07 REVOCATION OF PERMITS.
   When the work for any building permit issued is not being performed in
conformity to the detailed statement, plans or specifications upon which such
permit was issued, it shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner to notify
the owner, or his agent, in writing, that the work is being constructed in
violation of the permit and that such work must be suspended until a permit for
such deviation from the detailed statement, plans or specifications be obtained
or that such work shall be made to conform to the detailed statement, plans or
specifications upon which a permit therefor was issued.  If the owner, or his
agent, fails to comply with such notice on the service thereof, it shall be the
duty of the Building Commissioner to revoke the permit. Written notice of such
revocation, signed by the Building Commissioner, shall be immediately served
upon the owner, agent, superintendent or contractor in charge of the work, and
shall be posted on such premises, and it shall be unlawful for any person to
perform any work in or about such structure, building or premises after the
revocation of the permit and the posting of notice thereof.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.08 SURVEY BEFORE PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   Before a building permit for the construction of a new building, or
alteration or extension of an existing building is issued, the applicant for a
permit therefor shall submit to the Building Commissioner a survey of the
premises upon which such building is to be erected.  Such survey shall be
performed by a registered surveyor who shall stake out the premises and the
building site by offset, and such stakes shall be caused to remain in the
ground until final inspection of the building has been completed.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.09 ESTABLISH GRADE; INSPECTION FEE.
   Before issuing a building permit for the construction of a new building, the
Building Commissioner shall request the City Engineer to establish a grade for
such building.  After a building permit has been issued and constructed
commenced, but before proceeding beyond the completion of the pouring of
footers for such building, the Building Commissioner shall request a further
inspection by the Engineer.  The Engineer shall at such time determine whether
such footers have been constructed in accordance with the established grade. 
The Building Commissioner shall not permit continuation of construction beyond
the pouring of footers for any building until such inspection has been made and
the construction approved by the Engineer. 
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.10 OCCUPANCY PERMIT.
   No person shall occupy, move into, inhabit or use a building constructed or
moved onto any premises in the City, without first applying for and obtaining
an occupancy permit on a form prescribed by the Building Commissioner.  Upon
application for an occupancy permit, the Building Commissioner shall forthwith
cause to be made an inspection of the premises which is the subject of such
application.  The Building Commissioner shall not issue such an occupancy
permit until the construction, alteration or moving of the building or
structure for which a building permit has been issued has been completed in
accordance with the plans and specifications filed and approved in connection
therewith, until all necessary fees for building and other permits have been
paid to the City, and until all of the provisions of this Part Thirteen -
Building Code and other applicable ordinances of the City have been complied
with.  No occupancy permit shall be issued for a commercial building until
landscaping work has been performed in accordance with approved plans or until
an adequate bond has been posted with the Building Commissioner insuring
completion of landscaping in accordance with this Building Code.  (Ord.  2001-
49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.11 OCCUPANCY PERMIT FOR CHANGE OF USE.
   No occupant, operator, lessor or owner of any dwelling, building or
structure shall convey, lease, rent or otherwise change the use or occupancy,
and no person shall commence the changed use or occupancy of any dwelling,
building or structure, excepting changes in ownership or occupancy of
residential homes where no change of use will result until an occupancy permit
therefor has been obtained from the Building Commissioner.  Application for an
occupancy permit for change of use or occupancy shall be made on a form
prescribed by the Building Commissioner, but a statement as to the mode of
change of use or occupancy and the proposed date thereof must accompany the
application.  Upon receipt of the application the Building Commissioner shall
cause an inspection of the premises which is the subject of the application,
and no occupancy permit shall be issued unless the proposed change in use or
occupancy is in compliance with the provisions of this Part Thirteen - Building
Code and the Zoning Code of the City and unless all other ordinances and
regulations of the City applicable thereto have been complied with.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1305.12 FAILURE TO COMPLETE WORK OR SITE IMPROVEMENTS.
   Upon the failure of any person, firm or corporation, to whom a building
permit has been issued, to complete the work for which the permit was issued
within one year from the date thereof, or on failure of any such person, firm
or corporation to complete the landscaping and planting of lawn within 18
months from the date of issue, as provided in Sections
 1305.05 and
1305.06 hereof, such person, firm or corporation, and the owner of any property
in respect of which such permit was issued, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor punishable as herein provided in this Building Code.
(Ord.  2001-49.  Passed 11-13-01.)
1305.13  WORK STARTED WITHOUT A PERMIT.
   (a)   Where work for which a permit is required by this Building Code is
started prior to obtaining a permit, a penalty as set forth in subsection (b)
hereof shall be charged and the required permit fee.  However, the payment of
such penalty and fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the
requirements of this Building Code or any other law of the State or Ordinance
of this City.
   (b)   Whomever violates subsection (a) hereof shall be charged the
following:
      (1)   For the first offense, a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) or an
amount of double the required permit fee, whichever is greater;
      (2)   For the second offense, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00);
      (3)   For the third offense and any offense thereafter, a fee of three
hundred dollars ($300.00).
         (Ord. 2018-78.  Passed 7-10-18.)

   (p)    Buildings or Equipment Not Specified Above. The fee for
      a permit to construct, install or erect any building, structure

   (q)    Obstruction Deposit.  To protect City property from damage
      and to insure the completion of all construction work, the
      removal of temporary offices, tools and/or storage sheds
      and the satisfactory restoration of the property involved,
      a deposit is required, prior to issuance of a building permit,
      on all new dwellings, commercial construction or any
      construction deemed necessary by the Building Commissioner.
 
(1)    On every new dwelling:
Either a cash deposit of      $ 400.00
or a bond in the amount of    4,000.00

         commercial construction or any other type of construction,
         the amount of cash deposit or bond shall be set by the
         Building Commissioner at a figure he deems adequate.
         All deposits or bonds shall be subject to increase if the
         nature of the work warrants it or if damage during
         construction exceeds the amount of deposit or bond. When
         all construction work is completed, when all temporary
         office, tool and/or storage sheds are removed and when
         the property involved has been restored to a reasonable
         state of orderliness, then a final inspection shall be
         made, and if satisfactory, the Building Commissioner shall:
      A.    Where no damage has been incurred, authorize
         either a full refund of any cash deposit made or
         the cancellation of the covering bond;
      B.    Where damage has been incurred and has not been
         satisfactorily repaired by the owner or contractor:
         1.    Authorize the refund of any cash deposit remaining after
deducting an amount necessary to cover City costs for repair of all such
damage;
         2.    Authorize the collection from the bonding company or companies
of the amount necessary to cover City costs for repair of all such damage.

no bond shall be required, but a twenty dollar ($20.00) fee shall be charged
for inspection of the premises after razing.

shall be charged as a fee for  inspection after razing.

   1307.09 INSPECTION; FEES.
   (a)    When an inspection is ordered and is made in accordance with the
provisions of this section and the Building Commissioner finds the work
incomplete, a charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be made for each such
visit. For each inspection made necessary by faulty construction or inaccurate
information on a permit a charge of twenty dollars ($20.00)  shall be made.
(Ord. 1989-50. Passed 1-2-90.)
   (b)    Special Inspections; Reinspections.  Whenever a special inspection,
not a routine inspection of work being done under a permit is requested, there
shall be an inspection fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per hour to be charged at
a minimum of one hour per inspection and in fifteen minute increments
thereafter.
(Ord. 1991-56. Passed 11-12-91.)
   1307.10 GRADE AND LANDSCAPING FEES; BONDS; PENALTY.
   (a)   Grade Fees.  Upon the filing of an application and plans for a
building permit for any new dwelling, in addition to the permit fees set forth
in this chapter, the applicant shall:
      (1)   Post a cash bond in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) for each and every new dwelling to cover the following:
         A.   All costs of reviewing and establishing a grade, and inspection
thereof.  All costs paid to the City Engineer, in relation to the establishment
of the grade and final inspection thereof, shall be deducted from his cash
bond.
         B.   All costs associated with insuring that the rough grading of the
property is in accordance with the approved plans.
         C.   The cost of the City’s fifty dollar ($50.00) administrative fee.
      (2)   Upon inspection and approval of the rough grading by the City
Engineer, the remaining cash will be refunded, less the costs specified above.
      (3)   If the applicant does not perform the rough grading as provided
above, or if upon inspection, the City Engineer determines that the rough
grading deviates from the approved plans and such deviation is not corrected
within thirty (30) days from the date of the inspection, the applicant shall
forfeit the cash bond.
   (b)   Landscaping Fees.  In order to provide for proper drainage in the
City, whoever provides landscaping services for any new dwelling, including
subdivisions, shall:
      (1)   Post a cash bond at the time the occupancy permit is issued in the
amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for every new residential dwelling
to cover the following:
         A.   All costs of establishing a grade and inspection thereof.  All
costs paid to the City Engineer, in relation to the establishment of the grade
and final inspection thereof, shall be deducted from this cash bond.
         B.   All costs associated with insuring that the rough grading of the
property is in accordance with the approved plans.
         C.   The cost of the City’s fifty dollar ($50.00) administrative fee.
      (2)   Upon inspection and approval of the finished grade by the City
Engineer, the remaining cash will be refunded, less the costs specified above.
      (3)   If, upon inspection by the City Engineer, any deviations or
problems are discovered and such deviations and/or problems are not corrected
within thirty (30) days from the date of the inspection, the  applicant shall
forfeit the cash bond. 
(Ord. 2006-30.  Passed 12-12-06.)

CHAPTER 1309
Architectural Board of Review
1309.01   Establishment; terms; compensation.
1309.02   Qualifications.
1309.03   Officers; duties; report.
1309.04   Purpose; duties.
1309.05   Meetings; plan procedure.

1309.07   Application for hearing.
1309.08   Application for variances; hearings.

   Air pollution; emissions prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
608.07(b)(6)
   Plans and drawings - see BLDG. Ch.
1303
   Building permits - see BLDG. Ch.
1305
   Approving moved buildings - see BLDG.
1357.01
 
   1309.01 ESTABLISHMENT; TERMS; COMPENSATION.
   (a)    There is hereby established in the Municipality an Architectural
Board of Review, which shall consist of the City Engineer, the inspector of
Buildings, and the City Architect.  The City Architect shall be appointed by
the Mayor, subject to the approval of Council and shall serve for a term
concurrent with the Mayor; provided, however, that the Architect may be removed
by the Mayor with the consent of a majority of the members of Council.  The
City Planner and the Chief of the Fire Department shall serve as ex officio
members of the Board and attend meetings and make recommendations, but shall
not be entitled to vote.
   (b)   The City shall have a Plans Examiner appointed by the Mayor, subject
to the approval of Council and shall serve for a term concurrent with the
Mayor; provided, however, that the Plans Examiner may be removed by the Mayor
with the consent of a majority of the members of council.  The City Plans
Examiner shall serve as an alternate member of the Architectural Board of
Review.
   (c)   The City Engineer, City Architect, City Planner and City Plans
Examiner shall be compensated for serving as Board members on the same basis as
they are currently compensated for extraordinary services.
   (d)   The Inspector of Buildings and the Chief of the Fire Department shall
receive no additional compensation as Architectural Board members; their
service on the Board shall be considered one of their duties as Inspector of
Buildings and Fire Chief, respectively.  The architect-board member shall
receive compensation as may be fixed by Council.
(Ord. 2007-13.  Passed 2-13-07.)
   1309.02 QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)    The architect-board member of the Architectural Board of Review shall
be a registered architect authorized to practice architecture under the laws of
the State and shall have been actively engaged in the general practice of
architecture in the State for a period of not less than five years prior to his
appointment to the Board.
(Ord. 1978-16. Passed 7-11-78.)
   (b)    No member of the Board shall participate in the review of any work in
which he, or any partner or professional associate, is the author, or in which
he or they have any direct or indirect financial interest. (Ord. 1835. Passed
7-31-56.)
   1309.03 OFFICERS; DUTIES; REPORT.
   One member of the Architectural Board of Review shall be elected Chairman of
the Board and shall be responsible for the proper administration of its duties.
One member of the Board shall act as Secretary and shall keep or cause to be
kept in the Municipal Building a complete record of all meetings of the Board,
and he shall prepare and file with the Mayor and Council every six months a
report of the matters handled by the Board during the preceding six months.
(Ord. 1835. Passed 7-31-56.)
   1309.04 PURPOSE; DUTIES.
   (a)    The purposes of the Architectural Board of Review are to preserve and
protect the public health, safety and welfare by maintaining the high character
of community development and protecting the real estate within this
Municipality from impairment or destruction of value by regulating building in
the Municipality according to proper architectural principles and design, and
by regulating the use of materials, finished grade lines and orientation of all
new buildings hereafter erected, moved, altered, improved or repaired, and the
Board shall exercise its powers and perform its duties for the accomplishment
of such purposes only.
   (b)    The Board will use its architectural judgment in such a way as to
maintain the established physical characteristics of the various immediate
neighborhoods as a minimum standard for new construction, and commercial and
industrial buildings particularly shall be required to be designed in a manner
in keeping with their surroundings. When desired by the applicant, preliminary
studies of proposed buildings may be submitted to the Board for advice and
consultation.
(Ord. 1984-39. Passed 11-13-84.)
   (c)    One or more members of the Board shall examine and review the plans
of all buildings for the purpose of determining compliance with the
requirements of the Ohio Building Code and regulations of the Board of Building
Standards of the Department of Industrial Relations of the State adopted
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 3781.10, and all of the provisions of the law applicable
to such buildings. The Board or any of its members shall also be available to
the Inspector of Buildings for assistance in the application and enforcement of
the provisions of this Building Code and provisions of the laws of the State,
including the regulations of the Board of Building Standards of the State.
(Ord. 1990-31. Passed 7- l 0-90.)
   (d)    The Board will use its architectural judgment in reviewing any plans
for the erection of any new industrial or commercial buildings or for
alterations to any such existing buildings so as to encourage the use of
colonial design and architecture for any such buildings fronting on Brecksville
Road between Daisy Avenue and the Village Square.
   (e)    The Board shall hear and review all applications for variances from
the requirements of Chapters
1331 and
1335, but only to the extent that variances shall be granted for one, two and
three-family dwelling structures and only for such structures that are not
constructed of industrialized dwelling units. The Board may grant any variance
that is consistent with the definition of variance in Section
1309.08(b) and that is consistent with the intent and purpose of Chapters
1331 and
1335.
(Ord. 1984-39. Passed 11-13-84.)
   1309.05 MEETINGS; PLAN PROCEDURE.
   The Architectural Board of Review shall hold monthly meetings and such other
meetings as necessity requires, and shall receive and promptly review and pass
upon all drawings, plans and complaints filed in connection with applications
for building permits in accordance with proper rules and regulations adopted by
the Board. The Board shall immediately stamp its approval or disapproval upon
every set of plans, specifications and applications for permit submitted to it
and promptly return such application, plans and specifications to the Inspector
of Buildings.
(Ord. 1990-31. Passed 7-10-90.)
   1309.06 BUILDING PERMITS.
   (a)    No building permit shall be issued unless plans therefor have been
approved by the Architectural Board of Review. However, the Building
Commissioner may issue residential building permits for detached garages of no
more than 576 square feet, decks which will be located in the rear or side
yards, and storage sheds which will be located in the rear yard and which are
no more than 145 square feet, if the plans satisfy the requirements of this
Code and the Building Commissioner determines that review by the Board is not
necessary.
   (b)    No plans for the addition of the building wing, front or extension of
an existing residence building shall be approved when such addition, front or
extension is designed or intended to be used for commercial or industrial
purposes, and no building permit shall be issued for such addition, extension
or front to an existing residence building.
(Ord. 1993-13. Passed 4-13-93.)
   1309.07 APPLICATION FOR HEARING.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, at least five days prior to the day of
an Architectural Board of Review meeting, any applicant for Board approval
shall file a request for a hearing before the Board with the Inspector of
Buildings.  Such application shall be in writing stating the approval requested
and accompanied by all data, drawings and information otherwise required by
these ordinances. For good and sufficient reason, the Board may by the
affirmative vote of two members waive this hereinabove five-day filing
requirement.
(Ord. 1968-34. Passed 10-22-68.)
   1309.08 APPLICATION FOR VARIANCES; HEARINGS.
   (a)    Except as otherwise provided herein, at least five days prior to the
day of an Architectural Board of Review meeting, any applicant for a variance
shall file an application for a variance from Chapters
1331 and
1335 with the Inspector of Buildings.  Such application shall be in writing and
on a form provided by the Inspector of Buildings. The application shall be
accompanied by any and all data, drawings and information necessary for the
Board to determine whether or not a variance is appropriate in the specific
situation for which the variance is sought. For good and sufficient reason, the
Board, upon a majority vote of its members, may grant the variance. If the
Board determines to deny the variance request, it shall state the reasons for
the denial.
   (b)    As used in this chapter, "variance" means a modification of Chapters
1331 and
1335 permitted in instances where a literal application of such chapters would
result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship as a result of some
peculiar or unique condition or circumstance pertaining to the construction,
reconstruction and/or modification of a structure. "Variance" also means a
modification of the strict enforcement of Chapters
1331 and
1335 when the regulation sought to be varied does not result in the diminution
of the structural integrity of the structure for which the variance is sought.
(Ord. 1984-39. Passed 11-13-84.)

   1321.01 CONTRACTOR DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "contractor" means any firm, individual, co-
partnership, corporation, association or any other organization, or any
combination thereof, who or which, by himself or itself, or by or through
others, constructs, alters, repairs, adds to, subtracts from, reconstructs or
remodels any building, structure or appurtenance thereto, or undertakes, offers
to undertake, purports to have the capacity to undertake or submits a bid to
undertake any of the foregoing activities.
   "Contractor" includes general contractors, subcontractors and specialty
contractors or journeymen whose operations as such are the performance of
construction work requiring special skill and whose principal contracting
business involves the use of specialized building trades or crafts, and
includes those contractors who are engaged in the following types of work:
   (a)    General;
   (b)    Electrical;
   (c)    Plumbing;
   (d)    Heating and air conditioning; refrigeration, hydronics;
   (e)    Water, sewer, excavating and grading;
   (f)    Paving; and
   (g)    Specialty.
      (Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.02 REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person, firm, co-partnership, corporation, association or any
other organization, or any combination thereof, shall engage in a business or
perform any work or act in the capacity of a contractor within the City without
being first duly registered by the City to perform such work or engage in such
business.
   (b)    Such registration shall be issued by the Building Commissioner of the
City upon application. The Buildings Commissioner, before issuing such
registration, shall require satisfactory evidence that the contractor has the
ability and is qualified to perform the work for which the application for
registration is submitted.
   (c)    Any general contractor who will also be performing any of the
particular types of work listed in Section
1321.01(b) through (g) shall be registered to perform each such particular type
of work in addition to being registered as a general contractor.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.03 DENIAL OF REGISTRATION; APPEAL.
   Any person who, upon application, is denied a registration by the Building
Commissioner may, within ten days from and after such denial, appeal from the
decision of the Building Commissioner to Council, which shall promptly hear the
evidence of the applicant and of the Building Commissioner, and which may, at
the conclusion of such hearing, sustain, reverse or modify the decision of the
Building Commissioner. The appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with
the Clerk of Council who shall report the filing of such appeal and transmit
all papers so filed to Council at its next regular meeting.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.04 FORM AND TERM OF REGISTRATION.
   The form of the registration to be issued under the provisions of this
chapter shall be such as the Building Commissioner may prescribe. 
Registrations shall be required for each calendar year, and each registration
shall expire one year from the date of issuance.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.05 REGISTRATION FEE.
   The fee to be paid by any contractor required to obtain a registration under
the provisions of this chapter shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.06 REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   As a condition for the issuance of a registration to any contractor as
herein provided, such contractor shall give a bond to the City in the principal
sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000). Such bond shall be conditioned
on the registrant’s performing all work to be done by him as a contractor in
his trade in conformity with all of the laws of the State, the ordinances of
the City and the plans and specifications approved by the State or the City.
Upon default of such performance, the obligation of the bond shall become
effective. The form of the bond shall be such as the Law Director prescribes
and no registration shall become effective until such bond has been filed with
the Finance Director, with sureties thereon approved by the Building
Commissioner.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.07 VIOLATIONS; ORDERS TO CORRECT; CORRECTION BY  CITY.
   Any contractor holding a registration issued under this chapter who violates
any of the laws of the State, the ordinances of the City or any rule or
regulation prescribed by law or ordinance shall, upon notice from the Building
Commissioner, correct the work. If the work is not corrected within a
reasonable time after such notice is given, the City may cause such work to be
corrected and collect the cost thereof from the registrant or upon his bond.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.08 PROTECTION OF WORK.
   All contractors performing work pursuant to registration issued under this
chapter shall protect all work within public streets or grounds or structures
of the City by proper signs, warnings, barriers and barricades in order to
protect the public from injury by reason of such work. (Ord.  2001-50.  Passed
11-13-01.)
   1321.09 REGISTRATION REVOCATION.
   Upon the violation by any person registered under the provisions of this
chapter of any law of the State or the City, any rule or regulation prescribed
thereunder, or any reasonable order of the Building Commissioner made pursuant
thereto, the Building Inspector may revoke such registration, and such person
shall discontinue all work as a contractor during such revocation. Such
registration may be renewed upon further application and upon satisfactory
proof to the Building Inspector that any necessary corrections have been made
or violations abated, and upon reasonable assurance of compliance with such
laws, regulations and orders.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.10 INSURANCE.
   Each contractor applying for registration shall furnish evidence of
insurance for bodily injury in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000)
for each occurrence, subject to an aggregate limit of one million dollars
($1,000,000), and for property damage in the amount of one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000) for each occurrence, subject to an aggregate limit of one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000).
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.11 WORKERS’ COMPENSATION INSURANCE.
   (a)   The contractor shall, at his sole expense, take out and maintain,
during his registration with the City, Workers’ Compensation insurance for all
of his employees employed at the work site and, in case any work is sublet, the
contractor shall require the subcontractor similarly to provide Workers’
Compensation insurance for all of the latter’s employees, unless such employees
are covered by the protection afforded by the contractor.
   (b)   Such insurance shall be evidenced by a certificate from the Bureau of
Workers’ Compensation of Ohio that the contractor has complied with each and
every condition of the Act of February 26, 1913, as amended and supplemented,
known as the Workers’ Compensation Law.  The contractor shall save the City
harmless from any and all liability arising from or under the Workers’
Compensation Law.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.12 REGISTRATION WITH REGIONAL INCOME TAX ADMINISTRATOR.
   No registration shall be issued by the Building Commissioner authorizing any
contractor to engage in the activities listed in this chapter until evidence is
provided to the Building Commissioner that the contractor is registered with
the Regional Income Tax Administrator of the City.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.13 STATE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No registration shall be issued by the Building Commissioner
authorizing any contractor to engage in the activities listed in this chapter,
until evidence is provided to the Building Commissioner that the contractor is
licensed with the State of Ohio pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Ohio Revised
Code.
   (b)   All registered contractors with the City that are engaged in
electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning, refrigeration and hydronics
types of work, shall maintain a valid and unexpired license with the State of
Ohio pursuant to Chapter 4740 of the Ohio Revised Code, at all times, and upon
request by the Building Commissioner shall provide evidence to the City that
the contractor has a valid and unexpired license with the State of Ohio.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
   1321.14 EXEMPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any owner of a dwelling
personally performing work upon the premises occupied by the owner thereof, as
such owner’s established personal residence.  Such owner shall supply proof of
established personal residency, if requested by the Building Official.  Any and
all work performed shall comply with the rules, regulations, codes and
ordinances of the State of Ohio and City of Independence.  (Ord. 2018-77. 
Passed 7- 10-18.)
   1321.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord.  2001-50.  Passed 11-13-01.)
